objects.name: Creating an Ethernet Hub – SDN Part 2

objects.description: This module provides an overview of the concept of learning switches and hands-on exercises in which students use SDN to develop a learning switch.
objects.name: Creating a Learning Switch - SDN Part 3

objects.description: This module provides materials and hands-on exercises in which students develop a router using an SDN controller.
objects.name: Creating a Router- SDN Part 4

objects.description: This module provides materials and hands-on exercises in which students develop a network firewall which can take actions such as blocking, allowing, or logging traffic based on a variety of characteristics.
objects.name: Creating a Firewall - SDN Part 5

objects.description: This module will provide materials and hands-on exercises in which students will use SDN to gather statistics about the evolving state of their network.
objects.name: Gathering Statistics - SDN Part 6

objects.description: This module provides materials and hands-on exercises in which students will use SDN to create a network balancer based on various characteristics (such as network load, or “geographic” location of the source).
objects.name: Creating a Load Balancer - SDN Part 7

objects.description: This module provides will provide materials and hands-on exercises in which students will use SDN to make modifications to traffic within their network (e.g., to implement NAT).
objects.name: Modifying Network Traffic - SDN Part 8

objects.description: This module provides materials and hands-on exercises in which students will use SDN to implement QoS functionality within a network.
objects.name: Implementing Quality-of-Service (QoS)- SDN Part 9

objects.description: This module provides materials and hands-on exercises in which students will use SDN to implement network access control throughout a network, allowing policies to be defined and enforced to ensure that only authorized clients and activities are allowed.
objects.name: Implementing Network Access Control - SDN Part 10

objects.description: This module provides materials and hands-on exercises in which students implement traffic monitoring functionality at various levels throughout their network (e.g., for a given link, for a given flow, or network-wide based on a given criteria, such as any packet with a given source or destination).
objects.name: Monitoring Network Traffic - SDN Part 11

objects.description: This module provides materials and hands-on exercises in which students will use SDN to implement traffic isolation in a network (i.e., network slicing).
objects.name: Isolating Network Traffic - SDN Part 12

objects.description: This module provides hands-on exercises in which students will investigate mechanisms by which scalability and failure-tolerance can be implemented within SDN networks.
objects.name: Scaling SDN - SDN Part 13

objects.description: This module provides hands-on exercises in which students will investigate the security implications of SDN (both positive and negative).
objects.name: Security Implications of Software Defined Networking - SDN Part 14

objects.description: This micromodule reviews standard IP based concepts and then uses this background to contrast this environment with vehicular data busses.  Students are introduced to four data buses being used in modern vehicles: CAN, LIN, Flexray, and MOST.
objects.name: Vehicular Data Buses Part 1

objects.description: This micromodule reviews material from the previous micromodule ("Vehicular Data Buses Part 1") and then continues by discussing the security considerations for data buses.  While this is commonly taught material for IP based networks, this micromodule focuses on the specifics of vehicular data buses.
objects.name: Vehicular Data Buses Part 2

objects.description: This micromodule reviews material from the previous micromodule ("Vehicular Data Buses Part 2") related to vehicular data bus security and then continues by discussing the implications of having many wireless interfaces to modern vehicles.
objects.name: Vehicular Data Buses Part 3

objects.description: This micromodule will introduce students to the wireless physical layer and its vulnerabilities. The micromodule introduces and provides examples for two categories of vulnerabilities, namely active attacks and passive attacks.
objects.name: Introduction to Physical Layer Security and Spectrum Monitoring Part 1

objects.description: This micromodule will introduce students to examples of physical layer security used in real world wireless communication devices.
objects.name: Introduction to Physical Layer Security and Spectrum Monitoring Part 2

objects.description: This micromodule will introduce students to the concepts of spectrum sensing and monitoring in wireless communication applications. The micromodule provides an overview of why spectrum sensing and monitoring is important as well as provides examples of how it is accomplished in practice.
objects.name: Introduction to Physical Layer Security and Spectrum Monitoring Part 3

objects.description: Introduction to telecommunications; description of rate and latency, and bandwidth delay product; overview of circuit-switched networks and physical transport networks; description of packet-switched transport networks
objects.name: Internet Infrastructure and Telecom Part 1

objects.description: Control plane signaling in telephony networks; pulse and DTMF dialing; signaling set #7; packet-switched telephony including SIP.
objects.name: Internet Infrastructure and Telecom Part 2

objects.description: Introduction to mobile phone networks and their basic building blocks and history; technology path from 2G up through 4G wireless; GSM air interface and radio protocols; GSM core network architecture and protocols; SS7 and its use within the GSM core network; GSM voice, signaling, and mobility management protocols; GSM packet data protocols
objects.name: Internet Infrastructure and Telecom Part 3

objects.description: Core wireless communications technologies seen in 3G and 4G, including CDMA, OFDM, and MIMO; 3G protocol standards, including UMTS and HSPA, and their various protocol components; LTE networking, including air interface and core networking; voice services in 4G systems and IMS protocols.
objects.name: Internet Infrastructure and Telecom Part 4

objects.description: This module provides an introduction to several topics that are relevant to reverse engineering.  Students will learn about the general process of reverse engineering, legal concerns and ethics, and will be refreshed on the basics of x86 architecture and assembly.  By the end of this module, students will have a better understanding of what will be required of them in the course and the skills they will need to learn and will have reverse engineered (by hand) their first virus.
objects.name: Introduction to Reverse Engineering

objects.description: This module consists of a series of labs intended to familiarize students with the process of identifying potentially malicious files and to quickly attempt to understand their behavior through a process of triage.
objects.name: Malware Identification and Triage

objects.description: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background about text classification. The module is divided into three lessons, where the 1st gives the student a general background on text mining, the 2nd teach students how to extract important features from text, and the 3rd introduce efficient classification techniques to be used to classify the feature formerly mentioned.
objects.name: MACHINE LEARNING AND ANALYTICS

objects.description:
This unit consists of four modules. 

  1. HADOOP MAPREDUCE BASICS: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background about Hadoop and its popular framework MapReduce.

  2. HADOOP SETUP AND PROGRAMMING: This module aims to give the students a practical background on Hadoop setup and programming in MapReduce.

  3. SPARK BASICS: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background on Spark.

  4. SPARK SETUP AND PROGRAMMING: This module aims to give the students a practical background on Spark setup and programming.
objects.name: BIG DATA ANALYTICS

objects.description: This module shows how socket communications is used for communications between a client and a server. The TCP (connection oriented protocol) is used. A simple web server and a simple web client are developed in C# to communicate using the TCP protocol. A lab exercise is included to reinforce the communication using a web server and web client protocol for communications.
objects.name: M4.1: Simple Web Server and Client

objects.description: When performing reverse engineering activities, it often required to view network communication to gain a better understanding of your target software. This module will focus on analyzing application-layer protocols through PCAP files.
objects.name: Network Protocols for Reverse Engineers

objects.description: The goal of this module is to reverse engineer a program that dynamically resolves all the addresses for the functions (from the Windows API) that it uses.  It does this by first finding the base address of the DLL/module that it needs functions from, then walks the exports of the module to find the addresses. This complicates the process of analysis by obfuscating the function calls, making it more complex to determine the purpose of the program. Editor Note: This lesson may be referenced by multiple courses.
objects.name: Code Obfuscation

objects.description: The goal of this module is to reverse engineer a program that dynamically resolves all the addresses for the functions (from the Windows API) and create an IDA Python plugin that resolves all of the functions that will be called.
objects.name: Extending IDA Pro With Plugins

objects.description: This course introduces students to the basics of symbolic analysis and how it can be utilized for reverse engineering activites.
objects.name: Symbolic Analysis

objects.description: Brief introduction to SMT solvers and Z3.
objects.name: SMT Solvers

objects.description:
In this course, students will be presented with two activities of identifying malware network activity using a variety of dynamic analysis tools.

Lab Environment: Use of variety of tools is needed for this lab. It is recommended to do this lab in a virtualized environment.  The tools we will be using are ProcMon and Wireshark
objects.name: Monitoring Tools

objects.description: This module introduces students to three primary initial attack vectors: JavaScript attachments, office documents and social media.
objects.name: Malware Delivery Mechanisms

objects.description: The goal of this lesson is to work with JSDetox obfuscated JavaScript, Angler Exploit Kit, and PCAP of an Exploit Kit
objects.name: Exploit Kits

objects.description:
The following lab allows students to explore persistence mechanisms using the Windows API. The following are suggested resources:

  • MSDN documentation
  • Static disassembly tool such as IDA Pro
  • Dynamic disassembly tool such as WinDbg
objects.name: Malware Persistence Techniques

objects.description: This module introduces the basic concepts related to stepping-stone intrusion detection, provides preliminary knowledge, discusses topics in making a connection chain and packet sniffing, and summarizes all the important methods for stepping-stone intrusion detection in the literature.
objects.name: Introduction to Stepping-stone Intrusion Detection

objects.description: This module serves as an introduction to the Internet of Things (IoT), its basic architecture, and its top vulnerabilities. Different definitions of the IoT will be explored based on readings from publications by NIST and IEEE. Students will be introduced to the architecture and ecology of the IoT, as well as its top 6 vulnerabilities and real world examples of how they were exploited. Students will conduct a hands-on exercise for discovering and identifying devices currently connected in the IoT realm.
objects.name: Introduction to the IoT and its Security Landscape

objects.description: In this module, the TCPSimpleServer and TCPSimpleClient as well as the SimpleWebServer and the SimpleWebClient are tested thoroughly. While the TCP set only takes small strings as input, the WebServer/Client has several menu options and can exchange large files. A lab exercise is included to ensure that the process of communications is thoroughly understood.
objects.name: M4.2: Transfer Information Between Server And Client

objects.description: This module will discuss common malware privilege escalation techniques.
objects.name: Malware Privilege Escalation

objects.description: This module discusses common malware data compromise techniques.
objects.name: Malware Data Compromise Techniques

objects.description: This module will introduce students in static code analysis tools and options.
objects.name: Static Analysis Tools

objects.description: This course discusses open source code scanning tools.
objects.name: Open Source Code Scanning Tools

objects.description: This module will explore compiled versus interpreted security issues.
objects.name: Compiled Versus Interpreted Security Issues

objects.description: This module discusses the secure software development lifecycle.
objects.name: Secure Software Development Lifecycle

objects.description: This module will look at scripting for reverse engineers.
objects.name: Scripting for Reverse Engineers

objects.description: This module will introduce studens to creating metasploit modules.
objects.name: Metasploit Modules

objects.description: This module will introduce students to web application scanning for the OWASP Top Ten.
objects.name: OWASP Top Ten Web Application Scanning

objects.description: This module introduces students to advanced memory analysis using a debugger.
objects.name: Advanced Memory Analysis

objects.description: This module introduces students to investigative techniques for determining crash exploitability.
objects.name: Analyzing Crashes for Exploitability

objects.description: This course introduces students to EMET and EMET bypasses.
objects.name: EMET and EMET Bypasses

objects.description: This module introduces students to prevalant fuzzing frameworks.
objects.name: Fuzzing Frameworks

objects.description: This module will introduce students to effective fuzzing strategies.
objects.name: Fuzzing Strategies

objects.description: Apply previous knowledge about fuzzing and apply to real-world software.
objects.name: Fuzzing Real-World Software

objects.description: This module will introduce students for integrating fuzzing with software build/release process.
objects.name: Fuzzing Integration

objects.description: In this module, the SimpleWebServer and the SimpleWebClient are run and information is exchanged between them. A packet capturing program such as wireshark is used for capturing the communicating packets using the TCP protocol. A lab exercise is included to ensure that the process of capturing and sniffing is thoroughly understood.
objects.name: M4.3: Sniff Transfer Between Server and Client

objects.description: This module shows how socket communications is used for communications between a client and a server. The TCP (connection oriented protocol) is used. A multithreaded web server and a multithreaded web client are developed in C# to communicate using the TCP protocol. The client can be started with multiple threads on and the server is flooded with multiple requests. A lab exercise is included to reinforce the communication using a web server and multi-threaded web client protocol for communications.
objects.name: M4.4: Use SYN Flooding for DOS Attacks

objects.description: This module shows how socket communications is used between a client and a server, and to flood the server from multiple clients, where each client is a multithreaded application. The TCP (connection-oriented protocol) is used. The multithreaded web server and the multithreaded web client developed in module 4.4 are made robust to prevent them from stopping due to minor input errors. Multiple clients can be started with multiple threads on the same machine and the server is flooded with multiple requests. The performance of the server and the client is monitored using tools such as the Performance View within the MS Windows Task Manager and or Wireshark.  A lab exercise is included to reinforce the communication using a web server and multithreaded web client protocol for communications with multiple clients (on the same machine) and monitoring the performance of the server and client.
objects.name: M4.5: Monitor SYN Attack

objects.description: This is a brief module intended to foster discussion around bug chaining.
objects.name: Chaining Bugs

objects.description: This module shows how socket communications is used between a client and a server, and to flood the server from multiple clients on different machines on the network, where each client is a multithreaded application. The TCP (connection oriented protocol) is used. The multithreaded web server and the multithreaded web client developed in module 4.5 are used. Multiple clients are started with multiple threads on different machines and the server is flooded with multiple requests. The performance of the server and the client is monitored using tools such as the Performance View within the MS Windows Task Manager and or Wireshark.  A lab exercise is included to reinforce the communication using a web server and multithreaded web client protocol for communications with multiple machines, and monitoring the performance of the server and client.
objects.name: M4.6: SYN Attack From Several Client Machines

objects.description: This module shows how to harden a server that could be subjected to SYN attack. A lab exercise is included to reinforce the communication using a web server and multi-threaded web client protocol for communications.
objects.name: M4.7: Harden The Server To Monitor And Fend SYN Attacks

objects.description: Be able to monitor the flooding of the multithreaded web server that is subjected to a DOS attack, using requests from several multithreaded TCP web clients using C# and note performance and recovery of server for several such instances.  A lab exercise is included to reinforce the monitoring process.
objects.name: M4.8 : Monitor Performance Of Server For DOS Attack

objects.description: Be able to monitor the flooding of the multithreaded web server that is subjected to a DOS attack from several clients, using requests from several multithreaded TCP web clients using C# and note performance and recovery of server for several such instances.  A lab exercise is included to reinforce the monitoring process.
objects.name: M4.9: Monitor The Hardening Based On Attack From Several Clients

objects.description: This module shows how Caesar Cipher is used for encoding simple ASCII text. The concept of Caesar cipher is explained using hands-on exercises and the code for implementing Caesar Cipher is demonstrated. A lab exercise is included to ensure that the concept of Caesar cipher is understood.
objects.name: M6.1: Encrypt First Program Using Caesar Cipher

objects.description: In this module, the Caesar Cipher code developed in module 6.1 for encoding simple ASCII text is examined to see how it can be hacked – that is – how the Caesar Cipher code can be broken. Based on the concept of Caesar cipher, the program developed in 6.1 is used to demonstrate how to break the Cipher code. A lab exercise is included to ensure that the concept of hacking Caesar cipher is understood.
objects.name: M6.2: Ethical Hacking

objects.description: In this module, we will describe the divisibility of integers in the number theory. Basic divisibility properties will be given along with a few detailed proofs. Several lab exercises are provided for students to better understand finding factors of a given number and also important divisibility properties.
objects.name: M6.3: Divisibility of Integers and Their Properties

objects.description: In this module, we will describe the greatest common factor (GCF) of positive integers. Important properties of a greatest common factor will be reviewed. Students will explore two different ways to find GCF of two integers. They will practice writing a code for the Euclidean Algorithm a useful way to find the GCF of two numbers.
objects.name: M6.4: Greatest Common Factor and Euclidean Algorithm

objects.description: This module provides the basic definition of modular arithmetic and highlights its different properties. There will be a code associated that will demonstrate different properties of modular arithmetic and explain an extended approach to Euclidian algorithm.
objects.name: M6.5: Modular Arithmetic and Extended Euclidean Algorithm

objects.description: This module provides the basic information about the primality testing of large integers and determining the best possible algorithm. The module discusses two important properties of prime numbers and another important testing algorithm known as the Miller-Rabin test.
objects.name: M6.6: Primality Testing and Miller-Rabin Test

objects.description: This module communicates the general idea on how the block cipher works with the help of different algorithms and how to encrypt the plaintext by using Data Encryption Standard (DES)
objects.name: M6.7: Block Cipher and Data Encryption Standard

objects.description: This module communicates the general idea on how the public key cryptography works with the help of different algorithms and how to encrypt the plaintext by using RSA.
objects.name: M6.8: Public Key Cryptography and RSA Algorithm

objects.description: The learning objective of this lab is for students to really understand the impact of collision attacks, and see in first hand what damages can be caused if a widely-used one-way hash function’s collision-resistance property is broken. To achieve this goal, students need to launch actual collision attacks against the MD5 hash function. Using the attacks, students should be able to create two different programs that share the same MD5 hash but have completely different behaviors. This lab covers many topics including one-way hash function,the collision-resistance property, collision attacks, and MD5.
objects.name: Crypto: MD5 Collision Lab

objects.description: RSA is one of the first public-key cryptosystems and is widely used for secure communication. The RSA algorithm first generates two large random prime numbers, and then use them to generate public and private key pairs, which can be used to do encryption, decryption, digital signature generation, and digital signature verification. The RSA algorithm is built upon number theories, and it can be quite easily implemented with the support of libraries. The learning objective of this lab is for students to gain hands-on experiences on the RSA algorithm. From lectures, students should have learned the theoretic part of the RSA algorithm, so they know mathematically how to generate public/private keys and how to perform encryption/decryption and signature generation/verification. This lab enhances student’s understanding of RSA by requiring them to go through every essential step of the RSA algorithm on actual numbers, so they can apply the theories learned from the class. Essentially, students will be implementing the RSA algorithm using the C program language.
objects.name: Crypto: RSA Public-Key Algorithm Lab

objects.description: Transport Layer Security (TLS) is a protocol that provides a secure channel between two communicating applications so that the data transmission in this channel is private and its integrity is preserved. TLS is a layered protocol consisting of two layers. The bottom layer of TLS called the Record Layer, defines the format of the records used by TLS. The objective of this lab is to help students gain a hands-on experience of how data is transmitted using the Record Protocol. In the end students should be able to manually create, send and receive TLS Records. The lab exposes students to the TLS Record structure and how to program the various pieces of the TLS Record structure. The tasks in the lab enable students to have a deeper understanding of TLS key derivation, MAC calculation, TLS padding scheme for CBC ciphers and the difference ways TLS handles AEAD and CBC ciphers records.
objects.name: Crypto: TLS Protocol Lab 1 (Data Sending)

objects.description: Before a client and a server can communicate securely, several things need to be set up first, including what encryption algorithm and the key will be used, what MAC algorithm will be used, what algorithm should be used for the key exchange, etc. These cryptographic parameters need to be agreed upon by the client and the server. That is the primary purpose of the TLS handshake protocol. The objective of the lab is to help students understand how TLS handshake works from the crypto perspective. The TLS handshake protocol is responsible for negotiating a session, which consists of the following items: cryptographic algorithms, session key, and cipher suites.
objects.name: Crypto: TLS Protocol Lab 2 (Handshake)

objects.description: The learning objective of this lab is for students to get familiar with the concepts in the secret-key encryption. After finishing the lab, students should be able to gain a first-hand experience on encryption algorithms, encryption modes, paddings, and initial vector (IV). Moreover, students will be able to use tools and write programs to encrypt/decrypt messages. This lab covers the following topics:  (1) Secret-key encryption, (2) Substitution cipher and frequency analysis, (3) Encryption modes and paddings, and (4) Programming using the crypto library.
objects.name: Crypto: Secret-Key Encryption Lab

objects.description: This module introduces the host-based techniques to detect stepping-stone intrusion including content thumbprint, time thumbprint, packet count, random-walk, and crossover packets. We discuss three different types of content thumbprint method with their performance, and two different types of time thumbprint algorithms with their performance. Then we introduce the technique and its performance analysis for the method of using the count of packets captured. Stepping-stone intrusion can also be detected by applying the random-walk approach and analyzing the network traffic behavior. Finally, we discuss the method of using the number of crossover packets for stepping-stone intrusion detection.
objects.name: Host-Based Stepping-Stone Intrusion Detection

objects.description: We present two stepping-stone intrusion detection algorithms using random walk approach, respectively proposed in 2008 and 2015. For the routine detection algorithm proposed in 2008, the TCP/IP request and response packets in both the incoming and outgoing connections are monitored, then count the number of  packet, and compute the differences between them. If this difference is bounded, then it is concluded that the two connections are most likely a stepping-stone pair. RBRW algorithm developed in 2015 made use of the matched Send and Echo packets in the incoming and outgoing connections. This algorithm used the matched packet pairs to count the number of RTTs at the incoming and outgoing connections of a host, respectively. If the difference of the two numbers of RTTs is bounded, it is concluded that the host is used as a stepping-stone.
objects.name: Random Walk Detection

objects.description: Module I Week 1 Lesson 1.  Cyber Operations Law and Policy with course overview and comprehensive learning outcomes (Lesson 1 Part 1) and understanding technology and cyberspace (Lesson 1 Part 2).
objects.name: Overview of Cyberspace

objects.description: In order to overcome intruders’ time-jittering and chaff-perturbation manipulation, estimating the length of a connection chain becomes the main approach not only to detect stepping-stone intrusion, but also to resist intruders’ evasion. In this module, we discuss two methods to estimate the length of a connection chain to detect stepping-stone. One method is to match TCP Send and Echo packets by examining the sequence and acknowledgement number of the packets.  Due to the complexity of computer network traffic, this approach is only applicable to local area network which has no crossover packets. The other method that can be applicable on the Internet with crossover packets, is the approach of data clustering and partitioning algorithm, as well as resisting intruders’ manipulation by estimating the length of a connection chain.
objects.name: Packet Matching

objects.description: Most intruders tend to use stepping-stones to launch their attacks because the attackers can be protected by a long connection chain. However, using a host as a stepping-stone does not mean an actual intrusion. To reduce intrusion detection false positive errors, many approaches by estimating the length of a connection chain have been proposed since 2002 to detect stepping-stone intrusion. In this module, we introduced three typical approaches developed to detect stepping-stone intrusion based on estimating the length of a connection chain: Yung’s approach, the Step-Function method, and the Cluster-Partitioning Data Mining approach.
objects.name: Connection Chain Based Detection

objects.description:
Public key cryptography is the foundation of today’s secure communication, but it is subject to man-in-the-middle attacks when one side of communication sends its public key to the other side. The fundamental problem is that there is no easy way to verify the ownership of a public key, i.e., given a public key and its claimed owner information, how do we ensure that the public key is indeed owned by the claimed owner? The Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) is a practical solution to this problem.

The learning objective of this lab is for students to gain the first-hand experience on PKI. SEED labs have a series of labs focusing on the public-key cryptography, and this one focuses on PKI. By doing the tasks in this lab, students should be able to gain a better understanding of how PKI works, how PKI is used to protect the Web, and how Man-in-the-middle attacks can be defeated by PKI. Moreover, students will be able to understand the root of the trust in the public-key infrastructure, and what problems will arise if the root trust is broken.
objects.name: Crypto: Public Key Infrastructure Lab

contributors.name: scott sigmund gartner
contributors.organization: penn state school of international affairs

objects.description: Syllabus for Cyber Operations Law and Policy Course
objects.name: Principles of Cyber Law and Policy: Course Syllabus

objects.description: Brief introduction intended to provide student with the basis of understanding how to learn law coupled with examples from Bloom's Taxonomy.
objects.name: An Introduction - Learning How to Learn Law

objects.description: Module I Week 1 Lesson 2.  Cyber Operations Law and Policy Understanding Cyber Systems, Operations, & Technology Advances.
objects.name: Understanding Cyber Systems, Operations & Technology Advances

objects.description:
The lab module is about partitioning enclave software and observing the memory protection. Students are asked to place computation data differently in SGX and observe the performance difference for understanding memory protection.

Concretely, in Intel SGX architecture, the main memory is protected by the trusted processor and is isolated from the untrusted world. The isolation is enforced at the hardware level by mechanisms including memory encryption, integrity checking, as well as access control. The learning objective of this lab is an observable understanding of SGX memory protection. To make the hardware-concealed protection mechanism visible, we measure the performance difference of computation with and without memory protection. In this lab, we first set up the environment with Intel SGX SDK installed in our VM images.  We will then conduct a series of programming tasks and measure their performance when running computations inside and outside enclaves.
objects.name: SGX: Partitioning and Understanding Memory Protection

objects.description:
Software attestation is a two-party scheme to convince a client that the server runs a container loaded with the software image provided by the client and hosted in a trusted processor. Software attestation is a fundamental service in establishing a trusted execution environment (TEE) in a distributed system.

The learning objective of this lab is the use of SGX software attestation for remote applications. Students doing the lab will be able to write programs that call proper functions for enclave attestation in SGX machines. The lab focuses on the interfaces and functions for calling software attestation services in Intel SGX SDK. The lab treats the internal of software attestation as a black box and hides from students the various internal mechanisms (e.g., quoting enclaves for signing and measurement).
objects.name: SGX: Software attestation

objects.description:
With the advent of Trusted Execution Environments (e.g., Intel SGX), side-channel security becomes increasingly relevant and important. These TEE architectures are known to be vulnerable to side-channel attacks and leaving it unfixed would lead to consequences such as secret leakage and privacy violation. With the hardware vulnerability, it relies on the software development to ensure the security.

The learning objective is an in-depth understanding of the root cause of side-channel vulnerability, and the skills to develop practical side-channel attacks and effective defenses. Based on our SGX emulator that automatically exposes memory-access traces, we will have five lab exercises: The first two are about understanding the “data obliviousness” of two textbook sorting algorithms; data obliviousness is the fundamental property that affects the side-channel security. The next two exercises are about designing and developing functional attack strategy and defense mechanisms for sorting algorithms. The last step is about applying the learned analysis skills to computation beyond sorting.
objects.name: SGX: Side-channel attacks and defense in enclaves

objects.description:
With the popularity of cryptocurrencies (e.g., BitCoin, Ethereum, etc.), Blockchain, the backend technology that powers the cryptocurrencies, has raised to be a main-stream technique. It has the potential to disrupt many industries ranging from business, laws, finance, to many others.

The Blockchain provides the storage of transaction history in cryptocurrency and gives us an interface of reading/writing transactions. In this lab, the learning objective is for students to have a hands-on experience and in-depth understanding of Blockchain’s transactional interface. In addition, writing a transaction in Blockchain goes through the “mining” activity. This lab also introduces the basic concept of mining.

Lab Description: This module consists of four lab tasks: The first three labs explore the transactional and mining interface exposed by a Blockchain. The last two labs require designing client program to iterate and visualize the Blockchain transaction storage.
objects.name: Blockchain: Transactional storage

objects.description:
Lab Description: The Blockchain technology, while whose main application is storing transaction history in cryptocurrency, can be used in many other application domains. One common paradigm is to repurpose Blockchain for logging target applications and to increase the transparency.

The learning objective of this lab is for students to design and implement a simple service for secure distributed file system (SDFS) and use the Blockchain technology to log the service. The target system consists of a client supporting multiple file-system users and a server storing a file.
objects.name: Blockchain: logging remote file storage

objects.description: To protect the reputation and advance the profession of ethical hacking, it is vital that ethical hackers behave morally at all times, respect the rights of all citizens, and obey all applicable laws and legal authorities. This curriculum module is designed to equip ethical hackers, including penetration testers and cyber operators, in each of these 3 core areas. The 1st lesson teaches ethical paradigms for reasoning about right and wrong so that ethical hackers can proceed with moral clarity when confronted with ethical grey areas. The 2nd lesson covers the U.S. Constitution so that ethical hackers can understand and respect the rights of all citizens impacted by their activities. The 3rd lesson addresses federal and international statutes so that ethical hackers can abide by all necessary legal boundaries and authorities. It contains 3 lessons of approximately 1 hour each and a short introductory lesson so that it can be taught in a typical 3-semester hour week. This module was specifically designed to address the Legal and Ethics Knowledge Unit from the Academic Content criterion of the NSA Center of Academic Excellence in Cyber Operations program.
objects.name: Intro to Cyber Law and Ethics

objects.description: Includes smartphones and cellular communication platforms, and enhanced visual surveillance and cyber tracking.
objects.name: Cellular Technology, Enhanced Visual Surveillance, Biometrics & Cyber Tracking

objects.description: Includes an overview of unmanned aerial systems, UAS Regulation, and the use of UAS by Law Enforcement.  This will also include discussion of technologies that have implications for privacy and security concerns.
objects.name: Unmanned Aerial Systems (Drones)

objects.description: Includes understanding data & information sharing across cyber platforms and understanding who are actors & what are actors in cyberspace.
objects.name: Advancing Technologies, Data Sharing Across Platforms & Cyber Actors

objects.description: Includes discussion pertaining to the Congress, focusing on legislative and enumerated powers and the lawmaking process, and the President, focusing on executive power and the commander in chief and foreign affairs powers.
objects.name: Congress and the President

objects.description: Includes an overview of the US Court System and discussion of the Federal and State Court Systems.

multi-agency Coordination, and examples of cyber threats.

objects.description: This Lesson focuses specifically on domestic cyber crimes. For jurisdictional reasons that are explained throughout this course, federal law enforcement and intelligence agencies and the Department of Defense are tasked with cyber operations and cyber threat response in all matters involving national security and terrorism. State agencies assist with early identification and cyber threat information sharing with federal agencies, but with a few exceptions, federal agencies take jurisdictional precedence with these categories of cyber threats.
objects.name: Federal and State Roles in Cyber Crime Investigation and Prosecution

objects.description: Includes a CISA Overview, Changes Mandated or Facilitated by CISA, classified, declassified, and unclassified CITs and DMs, and Information Sharing Guidelines.

objects.description: Includes Evolution of Right to Privacy and the U.S. Constitution, an Overview of Warrants, and the Constitution and Government (State) Actors.
objects.name: Right to Privacy & Fourth Amendment

objects.description: Includes discussion pertaining to the First Amendment, what is free speech, right of anonymous speech & anonymity in Cyberspace; Subpoenas, the first amendment & online speech considerations, and First Amendment right of electronic surveillance of government actors in performance of public duties.
objects.name: First Amendment: Speech Protections, Anonymity & Surveillance

objects.description:
Includes:

1.The Fifth Amendment

  • Right Against Self-Incrimination

2.The Sixth Amendment

  •  Right to Trial by Jury; Right to Confront
  •  Sixth Amendment & Jurisdiction in Cyberspace

3.The Fourteenth Amendment – Due Process

4.The Constitutional Requirement of Standing
objects.name: Fifth, Sixth, & Fourteenth Amendments

objects.description: Includes discussion pertaining to existing federal statutory scheme prohibiting cybercrimes.
objects.name: Existing Federal Statutory Scheme Prohibiting Cybercrimes

objects.description: Includes other federal laws regulating access to data and criminalizing specific cyber activities.
objects.name: Other Federal Laws Regulating Access To Data; Criminalization of Specific Cyber Activities

objects.description: Includes discussion pertaining to Data Breach Laws, Electronic Surveillance Laws, Computer Crime Legislation, Electronic Stalking and Harassment Laws, Privacy Laws, Biometric Laws, Social Media Privacy Legislation, and Cybercrime Revenge Porn Laws.
objects.name: State Data, Surveillance, Computer and Privacy Laws

objects.description: Includes discussion of common law concepts such as:  Invasion of Privacy Torts, Other Cyber Torts, Contracts, Intellectual Property and Copyright Laws, and Evidence & Electronically Searchable Information.
objects.name: Torts, Contracts, Evidence, etc

objects.description: Includes discussion pertaining to the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and Federal Communications Commission (FCC).
objects.name: FTC & FCC

objects.description: Includes discussion pertaining to the role of international law, sources of international law, and international law and cyberspace.
objects.name: The Role of International Law in Cyber Operations

objects.description: This module is to use integer data types and their operations in a safe manner to avoid improper use of input or arithmetic operations. Incautious use of integer arithmetic to calculate a value for assignment to a floating-point variable can lead to loss of information. For example, integer arithmetic always produces integral results, discarding information about any possible fractional remainder.
objects.name: M1.1: Detect Integer Errors

objects.description: This module is to use different integer data types and their operations in a safe manner to avoid buffer overflow. Programs should not allow mathematical operations to exceed the integer ranges provided by their primitive integer data types.
objects.name: M1.2: Demonstrate Data Boundaries to Prevent Buffer Overflows

objects.description: This module is to validate input data by checking their type, length, and range. It focuses on checking exceptional values from floating-point inputs, not using floating-point variables as loop counters, and using conversions of numeric types to narrower types without losing or misinterpreting data.
objects.name: M1.3: Validate Input Data

objects.description: This module is to declare and use variables in a secure manner. It focuses on declaring and initializing variables properly to avoid confusion and minimizing the scope of variables to avoid common programming errors.
objects.name: M1.4: Declare and Use Variables in a Secure Manner

objects.description: This module is to use numeric data types and their operations in a safe manner to avoid unexpected results. It focuses on checking the divisor in division and modulo operations, avoiding the float-point numbers when precise computation is needed, and avoiding bitwise and arithmetic operations on the same data.
objects.name: M1.5: Use Numeric Types and Their Operations

objects.description: This module is to declare and use members of a class properly to control access. It focuses on limiting accessibility of fields of a class, not exposing private members of an outer class from within a nested class, and not returning references to private mutable class members.
objects.name: M2.1: Declare And Use Members of a Class

objects.description: This module is to validate arguments on method operations and to understand not to use assertions to validate arguments of public methods.
objects.name: M2.2: Use Valid Arguments on Method Operations

objects.description: This module is to catch and handle exceptions and unexpected behaviors especially when sensitive information is exposed. Programs must filter both exception messages and types that can cause across trust boundaries.
objects.name: M2.3: Catch Exceptions and Unexpected Behaviors

objects.description: This module is to ensure that Java source code conforms to secure coding guidelines, and to validate the secure coding using a static code analyzer such as FindBugs by performing a set of tests.
objects.name: M3.1: Perform a Set of Tests to Validate Secure Coding Using an Analyzer

objects.description: This module is to practice and ensure that Java source code conforms to secure coding guidelines, and to validate the secure coding using a static code analyzer such as FindBugs by performing a set of tests.
objects.name: M3.3: Demonstrate Extensibilities and Accessibilities of Class Members

objects.description: Through this module, students will learn to follow general rules when implementing the compareTo() method and ensure that keys used in comparison operations are immutable.
objects.name: M3.4: Demonstrate Use of Valid Method Arguments Within a Designed Boundary

objects.description: This module is to understand that sensitive information can be exposed through exceptions and learn how to detect and handle the sensitive information exposure with exceptions.
objects.name: M3.5: Detect and Handle Sensitive Information Exposure

objects.description: This module is to learn how to safely operate files and handle related issues. Students will understand that careless file uploading can cause arbitrary code execution on server-side applications. They will learn to prevent arbitrary file uploading, safely operate files, handle file related issues.
objects.name: M3.6: Safely Operate File and Handle Related Issues

objects.description: Through this module, students will understand that privileged blocks should not allow sensitive information leaks across a trusted boundary. They also learn to safely use validated or trusted data in the privileged blocks.
objects.name: M3.7: Operate Trusted Data In a Privileged Block

objects.description: This module is to learn and apply the concepts of the design principles for protection mechanisms, the principles for software security, and the principles for secure software design on a software development project.
objects.name: M5.4: Design Principles For Protection Mechanism, Software Security and Secure Design

objects.description: This module focuses on secure coding practices. Secure coding practices principles will be overviewed in a sequence of code analysis, code review, and program coding for developing a software system.
objects.name: M5.5: Coding Practices for Minimizing Risks and Vulnerabilities in Software Development

objects.description: This module focuses on practicing software security testing using different testing methods and techniques. The developed software from the previous stages can be tested by the methods and techniques. It is to ensure that the software system satisfies the functional requirements as well as the risk-based requirements identified in the specification.
objects.name: M5.6: Identify Security Test Cases of a Software Application

objects.description: This module emphasizes understanding software security testing and building a series of test cases using different testing methods and technologies. The testing methodologies encompass everything, from unit testing for individual modules and integration testing for an entire system, to specialized testing such as security and performance.
objects.name: M5.7: Conduct a Software Security Testing

objects.description: This module provides the foundation of conducting a security verification and assessment of a software application. The verification and assessment are overviewed at different phases of the software development life cycle.
objects.name: M5.8: Conduct a Security Verification and Assessment of a Software Application

objects.description:
The learning objective of this lab is for students to acquire programming skills in smart contracts and to develop basic programs. The lab will consider an educational scenario of smart contract, that is, the rock-paper-scissors game. The lab will be developed on Ethereum/Solidity platform using existing programming platform such as Remix. There will be programming exercises for students to implement two-party computation (e.g., max(x,y)) and three-party rock-paper-scissors game.

Lab Description: This module consists of two lab exercises and a bonus exercise. This helps in getting the grip on the solidity language used to write smart contracts which can be deployed on the blockchain. This lab concentrates on using the Remix IDE which is available to write, test, compile and deploy the smart contract, without need to set up any blockchain.
objects.name: Blockchain: Smart contract programming

objects.description:
Parts 1 and 2 of this Lesson address identification and initial investigation of a cyber threat. Proper identification and investigation of a cyber threat is essential because significantly different legal structures govern the handling of and response to cyber threats - depending upon the nature of the particular cyber threat.

From the standpoint of the law, determining the nature of the cyber threat will directly impact: what law governs; who should, and who can, respond; and what responses are lawful. This determination is based upon a three-fold inquiry:

(1) Who or what is being injured - government, business, individual, critical infrastructure?

(2) What type of threat is it - domestic crime, terrorism, national security?

(3) Who is the threat actor – state actor or non-state actor?
objects.name: The Cyber Threat-Response Framework: An Overview

objects.description: Includes discussion pertaining to Private Rights of Action under Federal Data Protection Law, Criminal Penalties under Federal Data Protection Law, the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA) 18 U.S.C. § 1030, and the Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015 (CISA).

objects.description:
Upon completion of this lab, students should be able to:

  • Explain the reasons for extracting statistical features from the preprocessed motion sensor data.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 1.
  • Develop code to extract simple statistical features in both the time domain and the frequency domain.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEPs 2 and 3.
  • Explain the relationship between time domain features and frequency domain features.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 3.
  • Develop code to extract advanced features such as the total energy statistical features.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEPs 4 and 5.
  • Develop code to save the extracted features to a file.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 6.
objects.name: Motion sensor data feature extraction

objects.name: Law and Policy of Cybercrime

objects.description:
This is the model syllabus for the Law and Policy of Cybersecurity Course. It provides links to readings for each of the course's micromodules. 

This course will survey federal and state cybersecurity related laws and policies, both those in existence and those being proposed in current legislative sessions.  These laws and policies will be assessed in the context of their U.S. civil, criminal, homeland, and national security implications. Additionally, the inherent international nature of cybersecurity will be addressed through analysis of internet governance and cybersecurity related treaties and international agreements.
objects.name: Law and Policy of Cybersecurity

objects.description:
Upon completion of this lab, students should be able to:

  • Create data structures to contain the feature vectors and label lists.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 1.
  • Construct the training and testing datasets by splitting the entire dataset.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 2.
  • Create machine learning models with training and hyper-parameters tuning for performing input inference attacks.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 3.
  • Evaluate the accuracy of machine learning models based on the test data.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 4.
  • Compare different machine learning models and their accuracy.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 5.
  • Analyze the impact of different features and datasets on model accuracy.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEPs 6 and 7.
  • Create machine learning models with training, hyper-parameters tuning, and evaluation for performing user fingerprinting attacks.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 8.
objects.name: Model training and evaluation

objects.description: In this module, the student will work with the Mirai Botnet source code to infect a router to use as part of a botnet.
objects.name: Mirai Botnet

objects.description:
Upon completion of this lab, students should be able to:

  • Interpret two representative data perturbation based defense techniques.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 1.
  • Construct new datasets by applying two data perturbation based defense techniques.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 2.
  • Create machine learning models with training, hyper-parameters tuning, and evaluation for performing input inference attacks using the newly constructed datasets.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 3.
  • Create machine learning models for performing user fingerprinting attacks using the newly constructed datasets.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 4.
  • Compare two data perturbation based defense techniques in terms of their effectiveness on reducing the attack accuracy.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEPs 3 and 4.
  • Estimate the potential side-effects of two data perturbation based defense techniques.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 5.
  • Propose new ideas to protect against motion sensor based side-channel attacks.
    • Assessed by the tasks and outputs specified in STEP 6.
objects.name: Motion sensor data perturbation for defense

objects.description: This module covers two topics: XSS and CSRF, and discusses the method for exploiting these vulnerabilities, and how to mitigate these vulnerabilities. We have module summary, slides, assessment, and visualization for two topics. We did not have hands-on labs for this module and users can refer to SEED lab for the hands-on labs on XSS and CSRF.
objects.name: XSS and CSRF

objects.description:
This module examines DNS Pharming and how it is implemented using Cache Poisoning, and how to mitigate these vulnerabilities.

This module shares its hands-on lab with the Ad Fraud module which we configure and set up DNS servers to achieve the ad fraud.
objects.name: DNS Pharming

objects.description: This module covers how digital advertising is serviced and their revenue models, as well as various types of fraud methods for generating fraudulent revenue.
objects.name: Ad Fraud

objects.description: This module is to take a closer look on sanitizing untrusted user inputs and validating those inputs. The examples of SQL and XML injection attacks are presented to grasp the concepts and to eliminate insecure coding practices and exploring vulnerabilities.
objects.name: M3.2: Sanitize Data and Validate User Input Across a Trusted Boundary

objects.description: This module is to ensure that a secure software Requirement Specification (SRS) is introduced at the early stage of software development life cycle by identifying threats, sources, defects, and security leaks.
objects.name: M5.1: Describe the Requirements for Integrating Security Into Software Development Lifecycle

objects.description: This module is to discuss detailed secure software risk management plans based on the secure specification at the Software Requirement Specification (SRS).
objects.name: M5.2: Apply the Risk Management on a Software Project Plan

objects.description: This module covers the security testing techniques, defect metrics, defects tracking, and exercises how to develop test case specifications.
objects.name: M5.3: Specify Functional Requirements and Identify the Expected Execution Plans

objects.description: This module covers the practice of software reverse engineering to analyze leaks. Static and dynamic analysis of the reverse engineering is introduced by using tools.
objects.name: M5.9: Use Reverse Engineering Tools to Perform Static and Dynamic Analysis

objects.description:
This module introduces the fundamental knowledge of encryption.
It has three micromodules:
1a. Symmetric Key Encryption (2 hours)
1b. Asymmetric Key Encryption (2 hours)
1c. Secure Hash Algorithms (2 hours)

This is Module 1 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have practical knowledge of basic internet technologies (TCP/IP, packet-switched networks, etc.) and basic exponential arithmetic.
objects.name: Basics of Encryption

objects.description:
This module introduces common secure authentication protocols.

It has four micromodules:
2a. Overview of Authentication (2 hours)
2b. Mediated Authentication Protocols (2 hours)
2c. Kerberos (4 hours)
2d. HOTP/TOTP (1 hour)

This is Module 2 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have practical knowledge of basic internet technologies (TCP/IP, packet-switched networks, etc.) and basic exponential arithmetic.
objects.name: Secure Authentication Protocols

objects.description:
This module introduces the fundamental knowledge of public key infrastructure.

It has two micromodules:
3a. PKI Basics (3 hours)
3b. X.500 (2 hours)

This is Module 3 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have prior knowledge of basic cryptography, TCP/IP, and networking fundamentals.
objects.name: Public Key Infrastructure

objects.description:
This module introduces real-time protocols including SSL/TLS and HTTPS .

It has two micromodules:
4a. SSL/TLS Overview (2 hours)
4b. HTTPS (1 hour)

This is Module 4 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have prior knowledge of basic cryptography, TCP/IP, and networking fundamentals.
objects.name: SSL and HTTPS

objects.description:
This module introduces real-time protocols in the network layer including IPSec and IKE.

It has two micromodules:
5a. IPSec Overview (3 hours)
5b. Internet Key Exchange (IKE) (3 hours)

This is Module 5 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have prior knowledge of basic cryptography, TCP/IP, and networking fundamentals.
objects.name: IPSEC and IKE Security

objects.description:
This module introduces wireless security including WiFi and Bluetooth.

This module has two micromodules:
6a. WiFi Security (WEP, WPA, WPA2) (3 hours)
6b. Bluetooth Secure Pairing (3 hours)

This is Module 6 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have prior knowledge of basic cryptography, TCP/IP, wireless network, and networking fundamentals.
objects.name: Wireless Security

objects.description:
This module introduces email security including PGP, MIME, and DNSSec.

This module has two micromodules:
7a. Secure Email Systems (PGP, S/MIME) (3 hours)
7b. DNSSec (3 hours)

This is Module 7 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have prior knowledge of basic cryptography, TCP/IP, email, and networking fundamentals.
objects.name: Email Network Security

objects.description:
This module introduces cloud security and has one micromodule:
8a. Cloud Security (3 hours)

This is Module 8 in the Network Security course, but the module could also be used independently.

Students should have prior knowledge of basic cryptography, TCP/IP, and networking fundamentals.
objects.name: Cloud Security

objects.description:
This class introduces the foundations of secure network communications. Beginning with a brief overview of cryptography algorithms, we then discuss what makes a particular sequence of messages to perform authentication. Notions of both Key Distribution Centers (used with symmetric-key encryption) and Certificate Authorities (used with asymmetric encryption) are discussed. Several key standards are investigated, including Kerberos, X.500, SSL/TLS and 802.1X.

Students perform exercises on pen/paper as well as through programming assignments. The course culminates in a multi-week project of the student’s choice: implementation of secure networked software; a research paper; or a testing project.
objects.name: Network Security Course Overview

objects.description:
This course introduces data privacy in a broad sense, with the aim of providing students interested in privacy issues
an overview of approaches and problems regarding privacy, and user attitudes towards privacy.  This course will expose students to
many of the issues that privacy engineers, program managers, CIOs, and designers deal with in industry.
objects.name: Privacy

objects.description: This module looks at the physical aspects of IoT security, such as teardown, interface analysis, and system access via UART peripherals. Students will learn about important hardware and firmware components of a device to investigate when attempting to exploit physical access to a device, and the majority of the module consists of a lab to exploit the Netgear Arlo base station.
objects.name: Hardware Security in IoT

objects.description: In this module, students will learn about the importance of authentication and authorization to the Internet of Things. Applications that utilize IoT devices must perform authentication to identify the machine they are communicating with, but there are many possible attacks that attempt to subvert this procedure. Different methods of performing authentication will be discussed, particularly digital certificates and public key infrastructure. This module has an in-class discussion activity about identifying devices using outdated certificates, as well as a hands-on lab about cracking weak passwords. The lab demonstrates how WPA2-PSK can be exploited on networks that use a weak password and what information can be gained from breaking the encryption.
objects.name: Authentication & Authorization in the IoT

objects.description: The Internet of Things is made possible by wireless communication, but there are a variety of standards operating at different frequencies that devices may utilize. In this module, students will be introduced to the security challenges of wireless medium, three common wireless standards (WiFi, Bluetooth, Zigbee), their security protocols, and potential attack methods. Students will apply this knowledge to perform a dictionary attack against a target network using the WPA2-PSK security protocol.
objects.name: IoT Wireless Communication Security

objects.description:
This module is designed to provide a general overview on the concept and topics related to designing a technology system to be used in an enterprise or "production" environment.

This module is Module 1 of the “Infrastructure Service Administration and Security” course, but the module can also be used independently.

This module is intended for undergraduate students for both technology majors and non-majors.

Topics include:

  • What is a production quality system?
  • What are adequate tools and appropriate tools?
  • How to implement using
    • Documentation
    • Support
    • Training
    • Allocation of resources
objects.name: Production Systems

objects.description:
This module has two parts. The first one is designed to introduce DHCP servers as part of a production environment. The second one is designed to introduce DHCP security issues.

This module is Module 2 of the “Infrastructure Service Administration and Security” course, but the module can also be used independently.

This module is intended for undergraduate students in information technology majors.

Topics include:

  • DHCP History
  • DHCP Servers and Clients
  • DHCP Handshake
  • DHCP Server installation on a Linux system
  • DHCP Denial of Service (DoS) starvation attacks

Prerequisite Knowledge:

Students are expected to have a basic understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, and TCP/IP networking. This includes:

  • Client / Server concepts
  • Using Linux command line interface
  • Installing Linux software
  • Configuring TCP/IP networking
objects.name: DHCP Intro & Security

This module is Module 5 of the “Infrastructure Service Administration and Security” course, but the module can also be used independently.

This module is intended for undergraduate students in information technology majors.

Students are expected to have a basic understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, and TCP/IP networking. This includes:
