objects.description:
This module has two parts. The first one is designed to introduce email servers as part of a production environment. The second one is designed to introduce email security issues.

This module is Module 6 of the “Infrastructure Service Administration and Security” course, but the module can also be used independently.

This module is intended for undergraduate students in information technology majors.

Topics include:

  • Email History
  • Email Servers and Clients
  • Email Server installation on a Linux system
  • SMTP brute-force authentication attacks

Prerequisite Knowledge:

Students are expected to have a basic understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, and TCP/IP networking. This includes:

  • Client / Server concepts
  • Using Linux command line interface
  • Installing Linux software
  • Configuring TCP/IP networking
objects.name: Email Server Intro & Security

objects.description: This module begins by examining the scope and definition of computer network attacks and computer network exploitation, then walks through the prevalent methodologies used to facilitate malicious network-side activities. The threat of botnets in the IoT is discussed, and data transport protocols used to communicate in the IoT are examined.
objects.name: Network Attacks and Exploitation in the IoT

objects.description: This module provides an overview of the different web application, mobile application, and OS-level threats that can affect devices in the IoT. Pre-built training tools for identifying application threats are introduced, and the importance of securing a device’s OS and firmware are explored in a lab where students build a custom firmware, compile a new kernel, and flash a router to change its functionality. The follow-up lab questions encourage students to reflect on the steps used to accomplish the flashing and analyze the device’s firmware update policies compared to recommended practices.
objects.name: Application and OS-Level Threats in IoT

objects.description:
In this module, students will be introduced to the forensic models of both traditional and IoT forensics, identify the challenges of forensics in the IoT, and test acquisition tools. Lesson 1 covers the models, approaches, and challenges to digital forensics, differences between the traditional and IoT environments, and the challenges when dealing with IoT forensics. A selection of four proposed solutions from current IoT forensic research are provided for students to analyze and write a reflection
about. The second lesson discusses objects of forensic interest in mobile devices, acquisition methods, and the selection of appropriate forensic tools. The role of network forensics and cloud forensics in IoT investigations are explored, and the module concludes with a short lab to test acquisition and examination tools for mobile devices.
objects.name: Forensics in the IoT

objects.description: This module provides an overview of current best practices for hardening the IoT environment, and introduces standardization efforts being put forth. Methods for establishing trust in an IoT environment, from the hardware to the software, are further explored with group discussion. Finally, students will evaluate government and academic initiatives for standardizing and hardening the IoT and write a reflection paper analyzing how they compare to each other and to established security practices
objects.name: IoT Standardization and Hardening

objects.description:
Course Name: Infrastructure Services Admin and Security

Prerequisites: This course is intended for undergraduate students in information technology majors with a strong emphasis on “hands-on” learning. However, students may come from computer engineering, computer science, information technology or any related technical field, provided that s/he has practical knowledge of basic internet technologies (TCP/IP, packet-switched networks, etc.), basic Windows administration, and basic Linux administration.

Course Description: Administrating Linux and Microsoft servers together to provide infrastructure services to mixed clients. Topics include: DNS, DHCP, SMB, web server, mail servers, authentication, and best practices for combining and mixing server platforms in an enterprise environment.

This course has 6 micromodules:
1. Production System;
2. DHCP intro and security;
3. DNS intro and security;
4. SMB intro and security;
5. Apache server intro and security;
6. Email server intro and security.
objects.name: Infrastructure Services Course Overview

objects.description: This module provides the foundation for later exploration of decisions in cybersecurity, including a survey of decision theory, a summary of relevant economic concepts, and a review of cybersecurity concepts. It also introduces a list of who the people are in human-centered cybersecurity.
objects.name: Economic theories of cybersecurity decision-making

objects.description: This simulation of a small company’s security policies provides students with an opportunity to make a couple of simple security decisions that have consequences both for productivity and security.
objects.name: Balancing competing demands for productivity and security

objects.description: This module is an overview of systematic violations of rationality in human decision making, specifically based on heuristic reasoning. The heuristics and biases framework explains these systematic violations of rational decision- making based on the limited resources available to human decision-makers.
objects.name: Heuristics and biases in cybersecurity decision making

objects.description: This module is a general overview of bounded rationality, which is the notion that humans adapt both to their external environment and to their internal information processing limits. The module proposes several mechanisms for this adaptation and applies those mechanisms to specific situations in cybersecurity.
objects.name: Bounded rationality in cybersecurity decision making

objects.description: This module is a general overview of signal detection theory, which is a method of differentiating patterns from noise, and also for reporting the accuracy with which a person or method can detect or recover a signal. The module describes how signal detection theory might be useful as an approach in various cybersecurity scenarios and invites students to explore how they might apply a signal detection framework to problems.
objects.name: Signal detection theory in cybersecurity settings

objects.description: This module provides a simulation of a signal detection activity designed to capture the signal detection features of monitoring a network. The module illustrates principles of signal detection in the context of multiple underlying distributions and with different response biases.
objects.name: Varying the signal to noise ratio

objects.description: This module provides learners with a general overview of mental models, how they are or can be formed, how they are used, and ways they can both facilitate and hinder shared understanding of a problem. The module will include information about mental models of viruses and other cyber threats, as well as mental models of computer security threats. Students will be asked to consider and discuss how user mental models can impact cybersecurity professionals, users, and others on the network.
objects.name: User mental models of cybersecurity

objects.description: This module provides information about social engineering as a technique for psychologically manipulating individuals to attain information, access a system, or commit fraud. Topics covered will include common social engineering tactics, vectors, and techniques as well as how cybersecurity professionals and users can identify and defend against social engineering attacks.
objects.name: Social engineering

objects.description: This module describes the basics of game theory and familiarizes students with some basic types of games. Students will also learn how to translate cybersecurity situations into games and how games can be viewed as a model of human behavior. K-level reasoning and Stackelberg games are also discussed in the context of how they might help us to understand and anticipate attacker behavior.
objects.name: Game theory and exploitation

objects.description: This simulation of an adversarial situation between hackers (attacking a network) and analysts (defending a network), gives students a chance to explore their own behavior in an adversarial situation.
objects.name: Varying the costs of attack and defense on a network

objects.description: This module is a general overview of the psychology of information search including the methods used in a variety of context. The module also covers different methods for stopping search and the advantages and disadvantages of each. Students should be encouraged to think about the principles of information search in the context of cybersecurity scenarios.
objects.name: Information search in cybersecurity settings

objects.description: This module introduces how design choices might have cybersecurity implications and provides students with a basis for evaluating existing designs for usability and security flaws. It is not meant as a comprehensive course in usability, but as an introduction to the inter-relation between design and security. Students will create prototype designs and generate and test hypotheses about how users will interact with their design.
objects.name: Interaction design in cybersecurity

objects.description: This module is designed to illustrate and help students think about how cybersecurity policies can have unintended consequences both within and outside of the realm of cybersecurity.
objects.name: Unintended consequences of policy

objects.description: This module covers computer and human strengths in security contexts, and positive and negative effects of human cognitive limitations. During this module students will be encouraged to think about designs for security applications that specify human and computerized tasks and optimize the balance between the two.
objects.name: Cognitive engineering better cybersecurity

objects.description:
This module gives a quick introduction to Unix, Linux, Kali, and digital forensic tools in Kali.

This module is Module 1 of the "Digital Forensics With Kali Linux" course, but the module can also be used independently.

This module is designed to be an add-on component to traditional digital forensics courses. As the name implied, this module has a strong emphasis on “hands-on” learning in a Kali Linux environment.

Prerequisites Knowledge: 
Students should have prior knowledge of digital forensics, computer network (TCP/IP, HTTP, DNS), operating systems (Windows, Linux), and cryptography (AES, RSA, PKI, Hash).

Topics include:

* Introduction to Unix, Linux and popular Linux distributions;

* Introduction to Kali Linux and digital forensic tools.
objects.name: Unix, Linux, and Kali Introduction

objects.description:
This module gives an introduction to Data Acquisition, Data Recovery, and File Analysis using Kali forensics tools.

This module is Module 2 of the "Digital Forensics With Kali Linux" course, but the module can also be used independently.

This module is designed to be an add-on component to traditional digital forensics courses. As the name implied, this module has a strong emphasis on “hands-on” learning in a Kali Linux environment.

Prerequisites Knowledge: 
Students should have prior knowledge of digital forensics, computer network (TCP/IP, HTTP, DNS), operating systems (Windows, Linux), and cryptography (AES, RSA, PKI, Hash).

Topics include:

* Data acquisition with DC3DD and Guymager;

* Data recovery with Foremost and Bulk_extractor;

* File analysis with Autopsy and the Sleuth Kit.
objects.name: Data Acquisition, Data Recovery, and Data Analysis

objects.description:
This module gives an introduction to Memory Forensics, Network Forensics, and other forensic tools in Kali.

This module is Module 3 of the "Digital Forensics With Kali Linux" course, but the module can also be used independently.

This module is designed to be an add-on component to traditional digital forensics courses. As the name implied, this module has a strong emphasis on “hands-on” learning in a Kali Linux environment.

Prerequisites Knowledge: 
Students should have prior knowledge of digital forensics, computer network (TCP/IP, HTTP, DNS), operating systems (Windows, Linux), and cryptography (AES, RSA, PKI, Hash).

Topics include:

* Memory analysis with Volatility;

* Network forensics with Wireshark and Xplico.

* Other tools like hashdeep, binwalk, and chkrootkit.
objects.name: Memory Forensic, Network Forensic, and Other Forensic Tools

objects.description:
This three-module crash course is designed to introduce the open-source digital forensics tools in Kali Linux to security students and professionals. Kali Linux is a popular Linux distribution designed for digital forensics and penetration testing which has hundreds of preinstalled open-source cybersecurity tools.

This course is designed to be an add-on component to traditional digital forensics courses. As the name implied, this course has a strong emphasis on “hands-on” learning in a Kali Linux environment.

Prerequisites Knowledge: 
Students should have prior knowledge of digital forensics, computer network (TCP/IP, HTTP, DNS), operating systems (Windows, Linux), and cryptography (AES, RSA, PKI, Hash).

Module Name
1. Introduction to Kali Linux
2. Data Acquisition, Data Recovery, and File Analysis
3. Other Forensics Tools in Kali
objects.name: Digital Forensics with Kali Course Overview

objects.description: Dr. Edward G. Amoroso provides an overview of the course and offers motivation for why an understanding of cyber security is essential for success in modern government and business.
objects.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity: Cybersecurity - Course and Overview

objects.description:
A six-step representational schema and proof types are presented that supports broad understanding of one-factor and multi-factor identification and authentication protocols.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: General Authentication Schema

objects.description:
A classic multi-stage attack on the Unix kernel provides basis for investigating the nature of complex vulnerability exploitation by expert offensive actors.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Classic Unix Kernel Attack

objects.description:
The blockchain data structure is explained in the context of chained hashing of transactional data combined with mining to create a tamper-proof audit trail.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Basics of Blockchain

objects.description:
Historical perspective is provided on the original United States Orange Book approach and how it provided early basis for modern cyber security criteria framework compliance.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Orange Book and Security Criteria

objects.description:
An overview of the most common foundational TCP/IP protocol attacks including simple scans, header manipulation, and sequence number exploits.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: IP Packet Attacks

objects.description:
An overview of the basic elements of cryptography is offered including cryptosystem definition, cryptographic algorithm strategies, network schema, and examples.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Basic Cryptography

objects.description:
Understanding the asymmetry of attacks and corresponding countermeasures is best accomplished in the context of a non-technical attack on a classic soda machine.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Classic Soda Machine Attack

objects.description:
The external connectivity inherent in a modern enterprise perimeter is shown to create serious exploitable weaknesses that lead to advanced persistent threats.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Enterprise Perimeter Weaknesses

objects.description:
The Kerberos protocol is explained in detail and shown to remove the need to use passwords for authentication across a campus of local area network.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Kerberos

objects.description:
Five-tuple pocket filter and firewall rules are explained in detail and shown to support gateway policies for web, email, and other ingress/egress services.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Packet Filter and Firewall Configuration

objects.description: Three-step worm design is explained and shown to create serious cascading risks for networks such as the public internet.
objects.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity: Worm Design and Operation

objects.description:
The use of public and private keys is shown to support secret, authenticated message exchange between Alice and Bob while addressing scaling challenges in traditional cryptography.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Public Key Cryptography

objects.description:
The original Bell-LaPadula model is introduced and shown to support military-style confidentiality security requirements for subjects and objects.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Bell-LaPadula Model

objects.description:
The use of signatures to detect attacks is explained and variants are introduced as motivation for behavioral analysis based on profiles.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Intrusion Detection Basics

objects.description:
A typical login program is used to explain Trojan horse code insertion to create trap doors that will avoid the scrutiny of code reviews.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Trojan Horse Code Insertion

objects.description: The three types of cryptanalysis are explained and an example linear, character substitution cipher is subjected to brute-force ciphertext-only automation.
objects.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity: Cryptanalysis

objects.description:
Approaches to key distribution for public key cryptography are explained and the certification authority infrastructure and secure sockets layer (SSL) protocol are introduced.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Key Distribution and Certification Authority

objects.description:
The traditional integrity assurance computer security model of Biba is explained and compared with Bell-LaPadula for operating system and application protection.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Biba Model and Integrity

objects.description:
The techniques associated with deep, full, and half scans are explained and practical considerations for enterprise are also introduced.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Basic Scanning

objects.description:
The RSA SecureID protocol is described in detail and analyzed in the context of man-in-the-middle attacks by an eavesdropper.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: RSA SecureID

objects.description:
The clever use of number theory is shown to serve as the basis for the RSA algorithm and Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange protocols. 

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: RSA Algorithm and Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange

objects.description:
Bots are explained along with their aggregation into Botnets. When botnets grow large enough they can be used to take down commercial websites.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Botnets and DDoS

objects.description:
The story of James Ellis and Clifford Cocks at GCHQ is outlined and shown as an interesting historical lesson in how innovation can be performed in classified environments.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: GCHQ Origins of Public Key Cryptography

objects.description:
The S/Key technique based on Lamport's password authentication over insecure communication is explained and analyzed.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Lamport's S Key Authentication

objects.description:
A simple algorithm is presented that allows a user to pass messages and the recipient will not know the sender but know the message is valid.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Chaum Blinding Algorithm

objects.description:
The DES algorithm is introduced and Triple-DES is shown to represent a design that fixes an exploitable weakness while maintaining compatibility with the legacy algorithm.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Triple-DES Compatibility with DES

objects.description:
The phases of cyber offense are mapped to the phases of cyber defense to demonstrate the challenges of identifying accurate indicators in real-time.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Cyber Offensive and Defensive Schema

objects.description:
An introduction to the NIST Cyber Security Framework (NIST 800-53) is offered in the context of practical government and enterprise infrastructure protection.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: NIST Cyber Security Framework

objects.description:
The design and network positioning of a cloud access security broker (CASB) is explained and shown to address security visibility and shadow IT challenges.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: CASB Design

objects.description:
Challenges in effective security awareness for enterprise are explained and the benefits of using new awareness methods based on video and social media are outlined.

This nanomodule is a lesson in the Introduction to Cybersecurity course.
objects.name: Reinventing Security Awareness

objects.description: This module is to provide students with an in-depth discussion of the threats and defense of the mobile and wireless IoT devices and their communications. It will present the specific threats and risks, the state-of-the-art security protocol, and the major challenges and mitigation measures.
objects.name: Wireless and Mobile IoT Devices Threats and Defense

objects.description: This module is to provide students with an in-depth discussion of the threats and defense of the Edge Cloud system. It will present the specific threats and risks, and the protection and defense measures.
objects.name: Edge Cloud Threats and Defense

objects.description: This module is to provide students with the hands-on experience of the threats and defense for the Edge-IoT system security. It will guide students to complete labs step by step from three aspects: confidentiality, integrity, and availability. The environment of experiments is provided by the campus OpenStack servers. The student will have the opportunity to perform the attacks and mitigations with their individual edge nodes.
objects.name: Edge Cloud Hands-on Labs: Threats and Defense

objects.description: This module is to provide students with the hands-on experience of the threats and defense for the Edge-IoT system security. It will guide students to complete two labs step by step from the angles of attack and mitigation. The environment of experiments is provided by the campus OpenStack servers and Raspberry Pis. The student will have the opportunity to perform the attacks and mitigations with their individual Raspberry Pis provided by university.
objects.name: IoT Devices Hands-on Labs: Threats and Defense

objects.description: This module is to provide students with a brief overview of the emerging technologies for Edge-IoT system security. It will introduce zero trust, blockchain, de-perimeterization and Software defined perimeter (SDP).
objects.name: Edge-IoT Emerging Technologies

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers international legal and policy aspects of cybercrime.
objects.name: International Aspects of Cybercrime

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers issues of jurisdiction related to investigating and prosecuting cybercrime.
objects.name: Jurisdiction in Investigating and Prosecuting Cybercrime

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers warrant requirements for searching and seizing digital information.
objects.name: Warrant Requirements in Cyberspace

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers major federal statutes pertaining to privacy.
objects.name: Federal Privacy Statutes

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers recommendations related to preparedness and response to cyber incidents.
objects.name: Preparedness and Response to Cybercrime Incidents

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers public-private sector cooperation in fighting cybercrime.
objects.name: Public-Private Sector Cooperation in Fighting Cybercrime

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers the major regulatory framework related to cybersecurity.
objects.name: Major Regulatory Frameworks in Cybersecurity

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers aspects of critical infrastructure protection and the NIST Cybersecurity Framework.
objects.name: Critical Infrastructure Protection and the NIST Cybersecurity Framework

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers the legal and policy issues related to encryption.
objects.name: Encryption

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers legal and policy issues related to data breaches.
objects.name: Data Breaches

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: Covers aspects of international law and cybersecurity.
objects.name: International Law and Cybersecurity

contributors.name: ben yelin
contributors.organization: university of maryland center for health and homeland security

objects.description: This is a model syllabus for a course on National Security, Electronic Surveillance, and the Fourth Amendment. The course is organized into micromodules with readings for each micromodules listed in the syllabus.
objects.name: National Security, Electronic Surveillance, and the Fourth Amendment

objects.description: This nano module contains the Syllabus, Instructor Guide, Key Terms and Literature, Learning Outcomes, and IRB documents.
objects.name: Course Logistics

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to cybersecurity in Industrial Control Systems (ICS). It is Module 1 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • General terminology and concepts in ICS
  • General cybersecurity practices in ICS
objects.name: Introduction to ICS

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to components and processes in Industrial Control Systems (ICS). It is Module 2 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Components in ICS
  • Relationships between ICS components
objects.name: Overview of ICS Components and Processes

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to network architectures in Industrial Control Systems (ICS). It is Module 3 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Network configuration and topologies in ICS
  • Zones and network segmentation in ICS
objects.name: Industrial Network Architectures

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to network protocols in Industrial Control Systems (ICS). It is Module 4 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Network communication protocols in ICS
  • Security problems with indutrials protocols
objects.name: Industrial Network Protocols

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to attacks on Industrial Control Systems (ICS). It is Module 5 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Common attack methods, targets, and vectors on ICS
  • ICS impacts and consequences
objects.name: Attacks on Industrial Control Networks

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to industrial malware and attack cases. It is Module 6 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Industrial malware cases like Stuxnet
  • ICS-CERT alerts and advisories
objects.name: Industrial Malware and Attack Cases

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to different security mechanisms to protect ICS. It is the Module 7 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Firewalls and security measures in ICS
  • Intrusion Detection Systems in ICS
  • Network segmentation in ICS
objects.name: Securing Industrial Networks

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to monitoring industrial control networks. It is Module 8 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. 

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Anomaly detection, even filtering and correlation
  • Threat detection
objects.name: Monitoring Industrial Control Networks

objects.description:
This module gives a brief introduction to risk and threat assessment in Industrial Control Systems (ICS). It is Module 9 of the “Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems” course, but the module can also be used independently. This module also include a final recap for the entire ICS course

Learning Setting: Online instruction.

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.

Topics include:

  • Cyber risk and threat assessment in ICS
  • Risk management in ICS
  • DREAD model
objects.name: Risk and Threat Assessment

objects.description:
Course Name: Cyber Security of Industrial Control Systems

Course Format: Online, Canvas-based remote instruction. 

Course Concept: This course is a textbook-based, online survey course designed to provide fundamental knowledge of cybersecurity threats to industrial control systems (ICS) and the security controls to mitigate those threats. The course is tailored to engineers with no deep background in computer networks or industrial control. 

Target Audience: This module is intended for graduate students in information technology, computer engineering, and computer science majors. The students may have widely varying backgrounds, so adherence to the text is important. Expect many questions of a fundamental nature during lectures.

Textbook: Industrial Network Security, 2nd Edition, Eric D. Knapp, Joel T. Langill, ISBN: 978-0-12-420114-9

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have a good understanding and previous experience with Linux, Windows, TCP/IP networking, Cybersecurity fundamentals.
objects.name: Cybersecurity of Industrial Control Systems

objects.description:
This course introduces students to network security. By examining case studies and reading seminal research papers, students will learn about network attacks and vulnerabilities as well as current defenses. Topics covered include cryptography, confidentiality and authentication protocols, firewalls, intrusion detection systems, privacy and anonymity.

This introductory course will impart a broad understanding of the underpinnings of security techniques, security best practices, and computer security research. The course should help students to understand the mindsets of attackers (the bad guys and gals who do malicious things on the network) and system designers and defenders (the good guys and gals who try to stop the attackers). The course should prepare students to understand and assess security threats, become familiar with security engineering best practices, and write better software, protocols, and systems.
objects.name: Computer and NW Security - Undergrad

objects.description:
Cryptography is everywhere in our everyday life. Whenever we connect to Facebook, shop on Amazon, call an Uber, our
device runs a sequence of cryptographic protocols that enable for secure communication over a public network such as
the Internet. In this course students will learn the concepts and the algorithms behind such cryptographic protocols: learn
how to formally define security properties and how to formally prove that a cryptographic protocol achieves a certain
security property.
objects.name: Cryptography

objects.description: Computer Security course explores several aspects of security research with the goal of understanding the attacker’s mindset. The class will help the students to develop a foundation and a well-rounded view of security research. The course covers some of the state-of-the-art attack/defense techniques and ongoing research activities in several topics in software security, web security, privacy and network security.

objects.description: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background on kill-chain phases using Mitre Att&ck. Recent studies have shown that most attackers use repeated attack pattern behaviors in executing their attacks. By carrying out attacks in phases, attackers can methodically complete their attack mission without being detected by defenders. Knowledge of these attack tactics and techniques can help defenders emulate known attack strategies and evaluate their defense strength and weakness in identifying and stopping these attacks. These phases include reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, exploitation, command and control, execution and maintenance. The early phase of the attack lifecycle consists of the reconnaissance, weaponization, delivery, and exploitation, while the late phase consists of command and control, execution, and maintenance.
objects.name: HIGH LEVEL KNOWLEDGE EXTRACTION AND KILL CHAIN INFERENCE

objects.description: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background of actionable insights from vulnerable data. With an increase in targeted attacks such as advanced persistent threats (APTs), enterprise system defenders require a comprehensive framework that allows them to detect these attacks. MITRE has developed a framework which includes a database of different kill-chains, tactics, techniques, and procedures that attackers employ to perform these attacks. By collecting data from different endpoints in an enterprise which include network and system call level traces, enterprise defenders can detect and mitigate APT attacks. By leveraging the MITRE ATT&CK framework, we build a system that uses the collected data to classify attack traces to tactics used by an attacker. A typical attack trace consists of various tactical actions as attackers leverage multiple tactics to achieve their goal. To detect these tactics, we formulate the problem as a multi-label classification problem.
objects.name: ACTIONABLE INSIGHT FROM CYBERTHREAT AND VULNERABLE DATA

objects.description: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background on Threat report classification using Mitre Att&ck Killchain and Tactics and Techniques framework. In Mitre Att&ck framework, tactics provide course-grained information representing whyan attacker is performing a particular attack, and techniques provide fine-grained information representing howan attacker completes an attack activity. When attacks occur, reports are usually generated to document such attacks, our goal is to categorize these attack reports to tactics and techniques to help understand attacker intents and actions.
objects.name: CYBER THREATS AND VULNERABILITY DATA PROCESSING

objects.description: This module focuses on practical aspects of private key and public key cryptography. It describes the mechanisms/algorithms that cryptography provides for symmetric and asymmetric encryption, key agreement, hashing, and digital signatures; it elaborates on how they are used to achieve the major pillars of information security including confidentiality, integrity, authenticity, and non-repudiation. It discusses the limitations of these mechanisms/algorithms and emphasizes the need for each of them. It also includes a discussion of the need for a PKI (public key infrastructure) and explains how digital certificates and certification authorities are used to provide authentication.

Students will also analyze the QKD protocol for detecting eavesdropping.

objects.description:
Principles of Cyber Operations Law and Policy Course.

Consists of the following modules:

  • Module I Understanding Cyberspace
  • Module II Cyber Governance: Three Branches of Government
  • Module III Legal Foundations of Modern Cyber Law and Policy
  • Module IV Cyber Operations

objects.description:
Module I:  Understanding Cyberspace

Includes the following lessons:

  • Lesson 0: An Introduction - Learning How to Learn Law
  • Lesson 1 (week 1): Overview of Cyberspace
  • Lesson 2 (week 1): Understanding Cyber Systems, Operations & Technology Advances
  • Lesson 3 (week 2): Cellular Technology, Enhanced Visual Surveillance, Biometrics & Cyber Tracking
  • Lesson 4 (week 2): Unmanned Aerial Systems (Drones)
  • Lesson 5 (week 3): Advancing Technologies, Data Sharing Across Platforms & Cyber Actors

objects.description:
Module III:  Legal Foundations of Modern Cyber law and Policy

Includes the following lessons:

  • Lesson 13 (week 7): Right to Privacy & Fourth Amendment
  • Lesson 14 (week 7): First Amendment: Speech Protections, Anonymity & Surveillance
  • Lesson 15 (week 8): Fifth, Sixth, & Fourteenth Amendments
  • Lesson 16 (week 8): Exisiting Federal Statutory Scheme Prohibiting Cybercrimes
  • Lesson 17 (week 9): Other Federal Laws Regulating Access to Data; Criminalization of Specific Cyber Activities
  • Lesson 18 (week 9): State Data, Surveillance, Computer and Privacy Laws
  • Lesson 19 (week 10): Torts, Contracts, Evidence, etc
  • Lesson 20 (week 10): FTC & FCC
  • Lesson 21 (week 11): The Role of International Law in Cyber Operations

Includes the following lessons:

  • Lesson 22 (week 11): The Cyber Threat-Response Framework: An Overview
  • Lesson 23 (week 12): Cyber Operations By and Against Private Actors
  • Lesson 24 (week 12): Shared Responsibility for National Security Governance
  • Lesson 25 (week 13): The Right to Conduct Cyber Operations Against International Actors (1)
  • Lesson 26 (week 13): The Right to Conduction Cyber Operations Against International Actors (2)
  • Lesson 27 (week 14): Rules for Conducting Cyber Operations Against State Actors (1)
  • Lesson 28 (week 14): Rules for Conducting Cyber Operations Against State Actors (2)
  • Lesson 29 (week 15): Rules for Conducting Cyber Operations Against Non-State Actors

objects.description:
Virtual networking is one of the key enablers of enterprise and cloud networking. When dealing with virtual networks, we usually need virtual switches for creating complex network topology. Virtual switching solutions such as Software Defined Networking (SDN) has gained a lot of attentions recently for its strength in managing large and ever-changing network infrastructures. But before SDN came into existence, Linux bridge was already a popular virtual switching tool, and it still is nowadays. A bridge, just like a physical switch, is a device to unite network segments transparently by forwarding the network traffic from the network devices connected to it. In this lab, we will first go through some Linux networking concepts and tools which can later help us understand the way Linux bridge works. Then, we will look into Linux bridge from both application and implementation perspectives.

 

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie  (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Linux Bridge

objects.description:
This lab covers the Open vSwitch (OVS), which is a software system that connects virtual machine (VM) instances to a layer 2 (or L2, data link layer) virtual networks. In network virtualization, virtual switches become the primary provider of network services for VMs. OpenStack Neutron supports multiple virtual switching techniques including Linux Bridge and OVS. OVS is a popular open source virtual switch that supports standard management interfaces and protocols including NetFlow and 802.1q VLAN tagging. In this lab, students will learn basic concepts of virtual switching (e.g., bridge, port) and basic functions and components of Open vSwitch. Students will also be instructed to use Open vSwitch in a series of exercises on switching in a cloud.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Open vSwitch

objects.description:
This lab covers OpenFlow, which is a software-defined networking (SDN) standard specifying the control of the forwarding plane operating on OpenFlow-compatible switches (including Open vSwitch (OVS)). OpenFlow enables SDN in which control and data/forwarding planes are decoupled. OpenFlow specifies a southbound protocol between controller and switch and defines the components and functions of an OpenFlow logical switch. In this lab, students will learn OpenFlow protocol, tables, ACL and basic concepts and programming of SDN. They will also practice on how to create, maintain, and close an OpenFlow communication channel between a switch and a controller, how to configure an OpenFlow switch using standard OpenFlow controller and switch procedures, how to explore and program tables in OpenFlow switches.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - OpenFlow

objects.description:
This lab covers SDN controller, which is an application in software-defined networking (SDN) that manages flow control to enable intelligent networking. SDN controllers are based on the network protocols such as OpenFlow that allow controllers to instruct switches how to handle packets (e.g., where to forward packets). SDN controller is the core of an SDN network. It connects northbound applications and services and southbound networking infrastructure. Network communications between applications and infrastructure have to go through a controller. In this lab, students will learn the basic concept of SDN controller by using OpenDaylight controller in a simulated SDN environment. Students will also learn how to find and examine the network topology through the user interface of OpenDaylight (DLUX), get familiar with the northbound interface through a set of common Representational State Transfer (REST) APIs, learn the southbound interface by analyzing the packet walkthrough between SDN controller and switch.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - SDN Controller

objects.description:
Overlay networking is building networks upon existing physical or virtual networks to provide one or multiple virtualized network layers. An example of a widely-used overlay network would be the Internet, which is built on top of LAN (Local Area Network) by introducing TCP/IP protocols. The advantages of using overlay networking include reusing existing network infrastructure, scalability and flexibility. In the context of cloud computing, network providers use a broad range of overlay networks to support complex cloud networking configurations. In this lab, we introduce two types of overlay networks that are popular in cloud data centers—GRE (Generic Routing Encapsulation) and VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN). Students will learn basic concepts of the two overlay network protocols, and practice network traffic analysis for GRE and VXLAN networks.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Overlay Networking

objects.description:
Security is critical to cloud computing. In a traditional network, network security is usually enforced by firewalls and dedicated network security devices. In cloud networking, we have a new mechanism—security group. A security group is a set of network filtering rules applied to a cluster of machines; the rules define the networking access to those machines. The concept of security group has been adopted by many cloud service platforms such as AWS, Azure, and OpenStack. In this lab, we will take a close look at the composition of security groups, and practice managing them on the OpenStack platform using dashboard or CLI. Finally, we will briefly explain implementation of security groups in OpenStack.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Security Group

objects.description:
Network intrusion detection is a critical component of network defense. Through effective network intrusion detection, malicious activities and policy violations can be monitored and detected. In this lab, students will learn how to conduct network intrusion detection using two popular open-source NIDS.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Network Intrusion Detection

objects.description:
Vulnerability discovery (or vulnerability scanning) is one of the most important mechanisms for proactive defense. With regular and periodical vulnerability scans, system and network weaknesses can be discovered in advance and many security incidents can thus be avoided. In this lab, students will learn how to use Nmap and OpenVAS to conduct vulnerability scans.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Vulnerability Discovery

objects.description:
The Internet protocol suite, also known as TCP/IP suite, is the foundation of the Internet. Vulnerabilities in TCP/IP protocols can have serious effects on the upper layer protocols and applications and can endanger communication and data security. In this lab, we will look into two TCP/IP protocols ARP and TCP, analyze their vulnerabilities, and show how they can be attacked.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - TCP/IP Security

objects.description:
This lab explains firewall rules and related theory and illustrates firewall configuration with examples. Students will play with iptables to get familiar with Linux built-in firewall software and common concepts about table, chain, and rules.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Firewall

objects.description:
Virtual Private Network (VPN) and its enabling technologies have been widely used for both securing remote access and evading firewall control. This lab focuses on SSL-based VPN such as OpenVPN and introduces the setup and operation of OpenVPN. In this lab, students will learn basic concepts of VPN and its deployment by setting up OpenVPN on server and client respectively. Students will use the deployed OpenVPN to access a web server in a private network.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Virtual Private Network

objects.description:
Certain old versions of Java are vulnerable to remote code execution attacks, which can be exploited by untrustworthy websites that provide services using Java applets. If a vulnerable version of Java is installed on a client’s computer, the client will have a high risk of being compromised when accessing a website that offers service through Java applet. In this lab, students will exploit the remote code execution vulnerability in an old version of Java to attack a remote computer through a maliciously crafted webpage.

For lab solutions, please contact Dr. Mengjun Xie (mengjun-xie@utc.edu).
objects.name: NetSiC Labs - Web Security

objects.description: Binary instrumentation allows dynamic manipulation of closed-source executables.  This module introduces binary instrumentation as a method for understanding the behavior of closed-source applications, including malware.  Students will become familiar with Intel's pin tool, a widely-used binary instrumentation framework and learn how to observe many aspects of an executable's runtime behavior.
objects.name: Malware Analysis using Binary Instrumentation

objects.description:
Please see Preface to Unit 1 that is included as a PDF for complete details.

This Unit reviews basic mathematical concepts needed for quantum computing and cryptography. It consists of nano and micromodules numbered 1 to 8. The files are still named nanomodule for easy sorting and tracking but if all the exercises are completed several of these will take 1-4 hours. Following is the list of modules included in this Unit,

1. The basics of complex numbers.

2. Properties of complex numbers.

3. Complex numbers on a plane.

4. Complex vector spaces.

5. Complex vector spaces: linear combination, independence, basis and dimensions.

6. Properties and operations on vectors and matrices in complex vector spaces.

7. Advanced concepts in complex vector spaces.

8. Overview of tensor analysis.
objects.name: Math Basics for Quantum Computing/Cryptography: A review (Unit 1)

objects.description: This micro-module provides an overview of CERT Android Secure Coding Rules which contains the rules and recommendations applicable to Android that are not specific to a language.
objects.name: CERT Android Secure Coding

objects.description: A content provider is used to manage and share data with other applications. When a content provider is declared public, sensitive information may be leaked to malicious applications. This micro-module discusses the vulnerability of leaking sensitive information through a public content provider.
objects.name: SENSITIVE CONTENT PROVIDER

objects.description:
An activity may be exported to other apps if an intent filter is declared for the activity. This may lead to other apps, including malicious apps to activate the activity for unintended use. This micro-module discusses the vulnerability of not restricting access to sensitive activities.

This module focuses on basic knowledge of java programming and the use of exploiting various intent filters. It focuses on the basic constructs and useful commands such as widgets, activity calling, and extracting valuable information to execute certain tasks during the lab assignment. During Module III, students will implement a malicious app that will have the ability to access sensitive information of another application.
objects.name: SENSITIVE ACTIVITY (SENACT)

objects.description: This module will discuss how sensitive information can be leaked if an app is released as a debuggable app and how to prevent the vulnerability.
objects.name: Debuggable Apps

objects.description: Logging is useful for debugging applications. Developers may log sensitive information such as password, credit card information etc. and forget to remove those lines of code before releasing the application. This micro-module discusses the vulnerability of logging sensitive information and explain some rules and guidelines which are specific to secure logging of sensitive information.
objects.name: LOGGING SENSITIVE INFORMATION(LOGSENINFO)

objects.description: This micro-module discusses the vulnerability of storing sensitive information on external storage. This involves writing a malicious app to read from external storage then modifying the malicious app to use internal storage.
objects.name: STORING SENSITIVE INFORMATION ON EXTERNAL STORAGE

objects.description: Data can be stored in shared preference in the form of key value pair. Shared preference stores data in an .xml file under application directory. Shared preference files can be uploaded using adb tool provided by Android SDK. This micro-module discusses the vulnerability of storing sensitive information in shared preferences, and how to prevent the vulnerability by encrypting the data before storing it in shared preference.
objects.name: SHARED PREFERENCES

objects.description:
Please see Preface to Unit 2 included as a PDF file.

This Unit builds on Unit 1 and discusses the basic concepts that are needed to understand quantum computing and cryptography. It discusses the notion of modeling of quantum systems, superposition, entanglement, quantum gates/operations, measuring of a qubit, single qubit and multi-qubit systems and operations, the EPR paradox and the CHSH game. If one completes exercises included in the modules in this Unit, it should take around 20-25 hours. Following is the list of nano and micromodules that are included in this Unit,

9. From Probabilistic Systems to Quantum Systems

10. Basics of Quantum Computing / Cryptography

11. Basics of Measuring a Qubit

12. Visualizing a Qubit

13. General Single-Qubit Measurement

14. Single-Qubit Gates and Operations

15. Multi-Qubit Systems

16. Multiple Qubits and Entangled Systems

17. The EPR Paradox and CHSH Game

18. Multi-Qubit Gates and Operations
objects.name: Basic Concepts for Quantum Computing and Cryptography (Unit 2)

objects.description: This unit introduces some basic kernel internals for Linux and Windows and then discusses kernel introspection and kernel-level exploits.  Various categories of exploits are examined and a longer-term project is provided that familiarizes students with discovering, understanding, and demonstrating kernel level exploits.
objects.name: OS Kernel Introspection and Exploitation

objects.description:
Please see Preface to Unit 3 included as a PDF file.

This Unit builds on all the concepts learned in Units 1 and 2 and discusses quantum cryptographic protocols that are built using them. It also discusses the relationship between classical and quantum cryptography and some of the attacks on quantum cryptography. The Unit also walks through simulations of the quantum cryptographic protocols through Python code as well as use of IBM quantum computer. The Unit provides several examples of simulation runs on the IBM computer. Following nano and micromodules are included in this Unit,

19. Classical and Quantum Cryptography

20. BB84: The first quantum key distribution protocol

21. B92: Quantum key distribution protocol

22. The three-stage quantum key distribution protocol

23. Entanglement based quantum key distribution protocol

24. The Goldenberg-Vaidman protocol

25. Quantum error correction codes

26. Attacks on QKD implementations

27. IBM Quantum Computers & Simulating Quantum Teleportation

28. Simulating BB84, EPR and the Three-Stage protocols on IBM quantum computer
objects.name: Quantum Cryptography and Advanced Topics (Unit 3)

objects.name: BROADCAST RECEIVER

objects.description: This micro-module discusses the vulnerability of allowing backup of SQLite database storing sensitive information, and how to prevent malicious applications from accessing data from a database backup. If the attribute android:allowBackup is set to true for an app, then all runtime app information such as shared preferences and databases can be backed up by anyone who has access to the device. Allowing backups is dangerous because your database and shared preference files will all be packaged together. These are the two most common ways of storing data on your Android device. So, if someone can back up your device, they could have access to all the data that you stored in those files.
objects.name: Database Backup

objects.description: This course introduces the organization of the cyber forces of today’s four primary cyber adversaries of the United States: China, Russia, Iran, and North Korea. The course, through a series of 15 modules, describes each country’s general organization of cyber forces and related intelligence operations. The course also describes issues in how the international community deals with cyber technology sovereignty and deterrence.
objects.name: Global Cyber Threat Environment

objects.description:
This module covers the basics of Modbus, client-server architecture, TCP/IP,  and networking attacks, with a focus on their applicability to SCADA systems.  Students will be introduced to Wireshark and Radzio software.  This module includes six labs.

This module should be completed following the first of the six SCADA module.
objects.name: SCADA Control System Networking - 2/6 SCADA Modules

objects.description:
This module covers the basics of SCADA networks and how denial of service (DoS) attacks work.  Students will also learn to use NMap to map networks and Low Orbit Ion Canon (LOIC) to perform DoS attacks.  This module includes six labs.

This module should be completed following the first of the six SCADA modules.
objects.name: SCADA Control System Network Enumeration and Denial of Service - 3/6 SCADA Modules

objects.description:
This module covers network packets and how traffic reaches its destination, including the use of address resolution protocol (ARP).  Students will learn about man in the middle (MitM) attacks and how to implement them using Ettercap software.  This module includes five labs.

This module should be completed following the first of the six SCADA modules.
objects.name: SCADA Control System Network Packet Alteration and Injection - 4/6 SCADA Modules

objects.description:
This module covers intrusion detection systems (IDSs), including their types, how they work, and how to use Snort to implement an IDS.  Additionally, machine learning in the context of IDSs is discussed.  This module includes six labs.

This module should be completed following the first of the six SCADA modules.
objects.name: SCADA Control System Network Intrusion Detection - 5/6 SCADA Module

objects.description:
This module covers the CIA triad (confidentiality, integrity, and accessibility), encryption, and authentication.  It also discusses the StrongSwan software and internet protocol security (IPSEC).  This module includes three labs.

This module should be completed following the first of the six SCADA modules.
objects.name: Adding Confidentiality and Authentication to SCADA Network - 6/6 SCADA Module

objects.description: This is a companion document to the published ACM volume Curriculum Guidelines for PostSecondary Degree Programs in Cybersecurity (CSEC 2017). CSEC 2017 provides the theoretical and conceptual knowledge essential to understanding cybersecurity as a computing-based discipline that includes aspects of law, policy, human factors, ethics, and risk management. Roadmaps are a two-step process which combine CSEC 2017 and relevant courses from an academic institution’s course catalog to create a matrix which explains what courses need to be taken by learners based on their individual work role goals. While the needs of each learner and requirements of each program may be unique, the Roadmap displays a holistic coverage of the important content. This is a roadmap document for courses offered at the George Washington University and can be used as an example to map the courses in your institution.
objects.name: CSEC Cybersecurity Guidelines - Mapping to NICE Workforce Framework

objects.description:
This module covers the basics of how Cyber Physical Systems (CPSs) and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA) systems work, as well as how to set up a virtual SCADA testbed.  This module includes five labs.

This module should be completed prior to any of the other five SCADA modules.

***DOWNLOAD VIRTUAL MACHINE *.OVA FILE IMAGE HERE: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1SvlwaT8oZgv2K8Bif_wrVNAOl9QNd_pc ***

objects.description:
This course is intended for undergraduate students in information technology majors to study cybersecurity fundamentals with “hands-on” learning. 

The course examines the study of planning and managing cybersecurity within a TCP/IP network environment. This is a case-study based course. Cases come from recent real-life cybersecurity breaches or exploits. Students look into case details and learn how these breaches could have been prevented. 

The course has the following 18 submodules:

8 subject modules:
Module 1: Dissecting Recent Cyber Breaches
Module 2: Email Security
Module 3: Web Security
Module 4: Network Security and DDoS Attacks
Module 5: Access Control
Module 6: Firewall and IDS
Module 7: Cryptography
Module 8: Malware

10 case study modules:
Module 9: Target Breach
Module 10: Anthem Breach
Module 11: DDoS Attacks
Module 12: IoT DDoS Attacks
Module 13: OpenSSL Heartbleed
Module 14: Equifax Breach
Module 15: Password Management
Module 16: Business Hacking
Module 17: CPU Meltdown
Module 18: WannaCry
objects.name: Cybersecurity - Overview

objects.description:
This is Module 1 in the Cybersecurity course, but the module could also be used independently.

Module topics: general introduction to cybersecurity, the Target case, the Anthem case, the current development in the cybersecurity industry, the job market 

This module is intended for undergraduate students in information technology majors with a strong emphasis on “hands-on” learning. However, students may come from computer engineering, computer science, information technology or any related technical field, provided that students have practical knowledge of basic internet technologies (TCP/IP, ARP etc.), basic Windows administration, and basic Linux administration. This includes:
•    Client / Server concepts
•    Using the Linux command line interface
•    Installing Linux and Windows software
•    Configuring TCP/IP networking
•    Basic web programming
•    Basic SQL statement

objects.description:
SCRIPTING FOR ADMINISTRATION, AUTOMATION, AND SECURITY 

This course focuses on scripting with PERL, Python, BASH and PowerShell to accomplish and automate common system administration, security and automation tasks such as working with files, network, web, and database interaction. The course has six submodules.

This is a very hands-on course with most of the work and learning taking place in lab exercises on virtual machines using a "learn by example" model where students can examine and analyze example scripts to then synthesize and create their own scripts to accomplish lab goals and tasks.

Students will learn scripting languages from scratch starting with the basics and build up from there. Scripts are developed on both Linux and Windows platforms with each topic being repeated in each language to illustrate both similarities and differences in the scripting languages and environments.

This course is intended for undergraduate students in information technology majors. Students should have practical knowledge of basic programming, basic internet technologies, basic Windows/Linux administration.

objects.description: In this module students will be introduced to the process of code review, learn how to perform a code review, and how to analyze issues resulting from a code review. Students will have the opportunity to find security issues in the code implementation of an open source project and report the vulnerabilities/issues found. Students will also use a static analysis tool to perform a code analysis of a simple java code and a complex java application (Lab option 1), or CWE/SANS Top 25 Errors for manual code review (Lab option 2), and using RIPS, a free static analysis tool for code review (Lab option 3).
