In the video for this module, I focus specifically on creating an E01 image using FTK Imager 4.2 using a Virtual Machine Disk (.vmdk) file. This is one of the beginning steps to conduct a forensic analysis.
objects.name: CREATE FORENSIC IMAGE FROM A VIRTUAL MACHINE

objects.description: This module focuses on the following software injection vulnerabilities and attacks, including code injection, command injection, SQL injection, JSON injection, XML & XPath injection, and XSS.
objects.name: Injection Vulnerabilities and Attack

objects.description: This nanomodule is an introduction to the course "Introduction to Strategic Cybersecurity," introducing its survey nature, noting the textbooks that the course uses, and briefly explaining the logistics of the course. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 1; Singer & Friedman, pages 12-16; and Geers, pages 9-18.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Strategic Cybersecurity

objects.description: This nanomodule focuses on two main ideas about digital information: how digital information is stored, and how that stored information is translated into textual data. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Singer & Friedman, pages 21-25 and 34-45.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Understanding Binary and the DNS

objects.description: This nanomodule offers a historical perspective of the development of the Internet, describing events that led to the rise of the Internet. These events include the development of the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA), The Manhattan Project, and ARPANET. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Naughton article; Singer & Friedman, pages 16-20.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Historical Foundations of the Internet

objects.description: This nanomodule provides a background of cyber conflict and considers deterrence systems (or lack thereof). A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Singer & Friedman, pages 21-25; Warner article; Ware/RAND report (Part A Only).
objects.name: Cybersecurity: The Bureaucracy of Cyber Conflict

objects.description: This nanomodule describes the classification of the Internet into five distinct layers (geographic, physical network, logic, cyber persona, and persona) and the vulnerabilities of each of those layers. The nanomodule also looks at common types of cyber-attacks. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 2; Singer & Friedman, pages 36-45.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Vulnerabilities and Vectors

objects.description: This nanomodule explains who are the United States’ adversaries in cyberspace (Russia, China, Iran, and North Korea) and their varying offensive cyber capabilities to effect various outcomes. The nanomodule also introduces the idea of Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs), which is how countries organize their capabilities to conduct cyber-attacks. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 3; Singer & Friedman, pages 55-60.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Adversaries and APTs

objects.description: The Treaty of Westphalia, signed in 1648, focused on the principle that “whoever rules the territory determines the religion.” This nanomodule explains this treaty and how it connects with cybersecurity. Though this course is not an international relations course, this topic is pertinent to the idea of sovereignty and the free flow of information. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapters 5 and 19; Singer & Friedman, pages 106-108.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Cyber Conflict and the Westphalian System

objects.description: This nanomodule discusses problems that cyber technology poses for international law. In particular, the nanomodule focuses on two aspects of international law that deal with the question of armed conflict: Jus Ad Bellum, or “the right to wage war,” and Jus In Bello, or “justice in war”. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapters 4 and 8; Singer & Friedman, pages 122-126.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Cyber Conflict and the Law

objects.description: This nanomodule discusses the problem of determining identity and attribution on the Internet. References are made to such events as “Ghost-Net” and Russia’s meddling in the 2016 U.S. presidential election via social media.  A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 6; Singer & Friedman, pages 31-34 and pages 72-76.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Problems of Identity and Attribution

objects.description: This nanomodule expands on the difficulty in determining computer intrusion attribution by discussing the challenges of constructing laws to deal with such criminal activity. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 7; Singer & Friedman, pages 85-91.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Cyber Crime and the Law

objects.description: This nanomodule discusses the concept of combining big data analysis with technical surveillance, or “dataveillance.” The nanomodule looks at two trends enabling the ability for dataveillance: nearly exponential increases in computer power and similar decreases in the cost of data storage. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 9.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Dataveillance

objects.description: This nanomodule discusses privacy concerns on the Internet. The nanomodule clarifies that concerns exist not just in the United States but also in the rest of the world. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 10; Singer & Friedman, pages 253-255.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Privacy

objects.description: Cybersecurity may be considered both a public and a private good, requiring cooperation and collaboration between the public and private sectors. This can be difficult, given the private sector’s typical suspicion of government assistance. This nanomodule discusses economics and government regulation in achieving cybersecurity. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapters 14 and 15; Singer & Friedman, pages 193-204.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Economics, Government Regulation, and Cybersecurity

objects.description: The U.S. government’s approach to protecting critical infrastructure from physical and cyberattacks has evolved over the past half-century, with presidential administrations creating various entities to better protect the country’s infrastructure. This nanomodule discusses this history and discusses the creation of Information Sharing and Analysis Centers, or ISACs. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapters 16 and 17; Singer & Friedman, pages 205-211.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Critical Infrastructure

objects.description: This final nanomodule of the course “Introduction to Strategic Cybersecurity” discusses topics for students to consider in the future. The nanomodule focuses on three primary concerns: the need for cybersecurity analysis to be interdisciplinary in nature, the adversarial realm that is concerned with destroying data due to perceived diplomatic slight, and the adversarial realm that uses Internet technology to spread “fake news” in an attempt to sow chaos in our political system. A quiz and activity are included in the lecture presentation. Supplementary material: Rosenzweig, Chapter 21; Geers, pages 63-87.
objects.name: Cybersecurity: Cyber Technology; Future Considerations

objects.description: This video introduces the Digital Versatile Disk (DVD) as a case study in unsuccessful cryptographic protection. There are three fundamental features of strong cryptography that DVDs failed to implement effectively.
objects.name: Examples of Weak Cryptography in DVDs

objects.description:
This nanomodule describes the roles of computer hardware in security and trust. The key message we want to deliver is that the computing and communication devices are not secure and they cannot be trusted for granted.

We will focus on the security vulnerabilities introduced by hardware. Threats from side channel attacks, hardware Trojan, and untrusted microchip supply chain will be discussed with illustrative examples. The module concludes with a high level overview of the key problems/challenges in hardware security, namely securing the design and design intellectual properties; securing the computation and data; and providing hardware security primitives.

Two detailed examples:

1. modular exponentiation and power analysis attack

2. trust in digital logic designs (both combinational and sequential circuits)
objects.name: Introduction to hardware security and trust

objects.description: Identity, Authentication, and Access Control are three core concepts that, respectively, help determine who someone is, verify who they say they are, and then allow them work and interact with a set of approved objects appropriate to who they are or what roles they fill. This module explores these concepts to illustrate them in the real world and in cyberspace. The module includes a variety of hands-on labs that help students build up and scaffold these concepts.
objects.name: Identity, Authentication, and Access Control

objects.description: This module introduces students to personal, governmental, and societal aspects of cybercrime. Students will learn when and how to report cybercrimes committed against them or people they know. At a broader level, students will discuss the possible types of cybercrime and profiles of cybercriminals. From an organizational perspective, barriers to responding, such as attribution and jurisdictional issues, are covered. Students will explore ways of preventing and deterring cybercrime from a law enforcement and policy perspective. At a societal level, the module discusses issues affecting particular people and organizations.
objects.name: Cybercrime

objects.description: This curriculum micro module provides a basic introduction to social engineering to help develop cyber security students’ abilities to recognize and defend against social engineering attacks. The basic premise of the micro module is that computer users and computer professionals must be aware of social engineering attacks, the consequences of falling victim to a social engineering attack, and ways to defend against social engineering attacks.The goal of the micro module is to equip the student with the awareness and tools necessary to recognize and defend against social engineering attacks This is a stand-alone, self-contained 1-hour module, with no knowledge prerequisites. It contains one lesson. This module can be incorporated into any university-level course that discusses cyber security as a part of the curriculum.
objects.name: Social Engineering Attacks and Defenses

objects.description: This module is a condensed introduction to cryptography that is suitable for inclusion in an intro to cybersecurity course for both majors and non-majors. It begins by discussing historical cryptography, and before transitioning to modern computer cryptography, reviews the basics of binary data encoding and presents a simple method for encrypting binary strings. The applied cryptography portion then follows which covers symmetric key cryptography, public key cryptography, digital signatures, the public key infrastructure, and cryptographic hash functions.
objects.name: Intro to Cryptography

objects.description: This module examines network defense fundamentals, including defining a security policy, attack methods, identifying risks, and securing networks.
objects.name: Network Defense

objects.description:
This module introduces the students to secure software development lifecycle and the testing strategies used to uncover

vulnerabilities in software.
objects.name: Secure Software Development

objects.description: This micro module will cover legal issues including laws, standard, current legislation and user policy agreements in the cybersecurity arena.
objects.name: Introduction to Cybersecurity Legal Issues

objects.description:
DESCRIPTION

This module will introduce the student to wireless networking protocols (IEEE 802.11N, AC) and current commercial and personal usage. In addition, the student will be introduced to the IEEE 802.11i WIFI security standard and security best practices to secure WIFI services. Students will install a wireless router and apply security features as a hands-on exercise.
objects.name: Wireless Security Module

objects.description: This micromodule, part of “Identity, Authentication, and Access Controls” module, teaches fundamental knowledge and skills on computer security access controls for undergraduate audience. An instructor teaching this micromodule covers the fundamentals of security access controls, including basics of passwords, different underlying principles (e.g., principle of least privilege), classical theory (e.g., Bell-LaPadula Model), the impact of failed access controls (e.g., malware), concept of capability, etc.
objects.name: Access Control

objects.description:
Reverse engineering involves deep analysis of the code, structure, and functionality of software using both static and dynamic methods.  This course provides a solid foundation in reverse engineering, which is crucial to understanding modern malicious software and in crafting potential solutions to recover from and prevent attacks.  Reverse engineering is also useful for creating interoperable software, for verifying that software patches function as promised, and for the simple joy of understanding at a deep level how software works.

You’ll be looking at complicated software from the “other end”, generally using assembler language listings.  All of the documentation, most or all of the variable names, most of the high-level structure  Many malware instances will deliberately try to make your job harder—for example, they’ll detect that you’re trying to use a debugger, detect that you’re running analysis tools in VMWare, employ encryption to prevent you from analyzing their code easily, and generally try to outwit you.  Sound fun?  You’re in the right class.
objects.name: Reverse Engineering

objects.description:
This lesson introduces quantum error correction codes. We will learn Shor's bit-flip and phase-flip error correction codes and how it can be used to correct arbitrary single-qubit errors.

Note: To get started with Jupyter notebooks please follow the userguide available at: https://sites.google.com/unomaha.edu/userguideqcl/
objects.name: Quantum Computing and Cryptography - 25: Quantum Error Correction Codes

objects.description:
Java code examples for symmetry.

This demo shows the violation of symmetry when overriding “equals” methods and shows how to prevent it. Besides, it also shows how to override the “hashcode” method

 

Hint

 

Trough running “Noncompliant.java” method we can see that “cis.equals(s)” wil return true but “s.equals(cis)” will return false, which violates the symmetry rule. To avoid it, you need to rewrite the “equals” method to let two results are the same. Besides, We have provide the right “hashcode” method. You can see that if the Strings are different, the return value of “hashcode” will be different. But if they are same, the result will be same, too.
objects.name: Java Symmetry Rule Enforcement code examples

objects.description:
Java code examples for transitivity.

This demo shows the violation of transitivity when rewriting equals method and shows how to prevent it.

 

Hint

In “Noncompliant.java” file, p1 equals p2, p2 equals p3. However, p1 doesn’t equal p3. This result doesn’t obey the transitivity. You need to rewrite “equal” method. (Considering a more strict judgment.)
objects.name: Java Transitivity Rule code example

objects.description: This course addresses vulnerabilities in the Internet of Things (IoT) and the challenges it presents when conducting forensic examinations. Many different facets of IoT security are discussed, ranging from software to hardware to network vulnerabilities. Through a combination of lectures, hands-on labs, and reflection upon recent case studies and research, students will learn about the threat landscape and best practices for securing an IoT environment. Lab activities will include: device discovery with Shodan, firmware modification, hardware exploitation, a WPA2-PSK dictionary attack, and testing forensic tools.
objects.name: IoT Security and Forensics

objects.description:
This is a new course curriculum for teaching malware analysis at the university level. The learning objective includes building practical skills in malware analysis using software instrumentation and machine introspection techniques.

The pedagogical effect of this form of learning means students will participate actively in dissecting and analyzing malware, not just with existing security tools, but also using their software engineering skills to design and develop custom tools utilizing APIs of popular instrumentation frameworks. Our model implements some of the design principles in teaching malware analysis (theory and practice, active learning and grand challenge) as outlined in the work of Shashidhar -Teaching Malware Analysis: The Design Philosophy of a Model Curriculum.
objects.name: Introducing Active Learning to Malware Analysis Curriculum

objects.description: The capstone course delivers the tenets of stepping-stone intrusion detection and prevention. Intrusion Detection focuses on the methods to detect attempts (attacks or intrusions) to compromise the confidentiality, integrity or availability of an information system. It includes the introduction to Stepping-stone Intrusion Detection, Host-based intrusion detection, packet matching, Connection chain-based stepping-stone intrusion detection, and random-walk detection. To help students to better understand the contents developed, we design ten hands-on labs including 1) setting up a stepping-stone intrusion connection chain; 2) capturing TCP/IP packets using wireshark/Tcpdump; 3) Making programs to capture network traffic; 4) content-based thumbprint detection; 5) time-based thumbprint detection; 6) stepping-function detection; 7) packet matching; 8) RTT-based random-walk detection; 9) Estimating the length of a long connection chain; 10) crossover packets detection.
objects.name: Stepping-stone Intrusion and its Detection

objects.description: Malicious injections may leak confidential information to the attacker or cause a system crash, malicious database manipulation, and even database corruption. This module addresses input validation, normalization, and sanitization, including proper data declaration and initialization, secure and privacy sensitive exception handling.
objects.name: Input Validation

objects.description: This micromodule is part of the Intro to Cyber course. The micro-module focuses on students recognizing the trade-offs associated with confidentiality and availability with respect to their digital footprint. The micro-module also contains a discussion on privacy attitudes and laws in different cultures and contexts.
objects.name: Privacy Micromodule

objects.description: This module covers categories of cybersecurity attacks and how to mitigate them. Students will be introduced to types of attacks, who the attackers are, malware, different types of attack frameworks and mitigation techniques for specific attacks.
objects.name: Attack and Defense

objects.description: Risk Management is a critical Cybersecurity infrastructure, which involves comprehension of organizational assets, threats, and vulnerabilities.
objects.name: Risk Management

objects.description: This module contains four hands-on labs that will teach students how to use a Linux-based environment for performing essential network exercises such as port scanning, host firewall configuration, and packet analysis. Common tools and programs like Nmap, Wireshark, and IPtables will be utilized to demonstrate real-world cybersecurity concepts and concerns. Students will apply their knowledge of common network protocols like TCP/UDP, HTTP, DNS, and ICMP to evaluate network traffic.
objects.name: Network Essentials Labs

objects.description: This module contains one lab manual that will walk students through the procedure of installing the free hypervisor program VirtualBox, with further instructions for installing four different virtual machines. Different VMs use different installation methods, including both pre-built and fresh disk images. The module is intended to serve as pre-lab preparation for Fordham’s other hands-on lab activities that will use various combinations of the VMs included here. We recommend that students only install the VMs they will need for the particular labs selected by their instructor.
objects.name: Virtual Machine Setup

objects.description: This unit provides a selection of hands-on lab exercises that address important intrusion detection skills and topics. It contains one micromodule on performing packet analysis to identify security events and one module that addresses intrusion detection systems and log analysis with 3 different labs. Students will use virtual machines with programs like Snort and Wireshark installed to analyze provided files and their own generated lab data.
objects.name: Hands-On Intrusion Detection Labs

objects.description: This micromodule contains one hands-on lab that will develop proficiency in analyzing network traffic by directly examining captured packets. The students will learn how to use Wireshark to capture and analyze packets while becoming more familiar with different network protocol headers and the important information they contain. Once learning the basics, the students will develop more advanced proficiency in analyzing network traffic by directly examining captured packets. The students will practice using the tools Wireshark and Tshark to draw conclusions from packets captured during different attack scenarios. They will use their knowledge of network protocols to evaluate what happened in the attacks and extract important data from the captured traffic.
objects.name: Packet Analysis Lab

objects.description: This module contains three labs that will develop foundations in intrusion detection theory with practical hands-on exercises. The students will learn how to use rule-based Intrusion Detection Systems such as Snort, as well as understand different types of log files and how to manually extract relevant data from them – including Windows Event Logs, network monitoring logs, and web application firewall logs. Being able to work with these tools and recognize how they gather their data is critical for correctly detecting and identifying security events.
objects.name: Intrusion Detection Labs

objects.description: This unit contains four sub-modules that address different aspects of penetration testing skills and topics. It begins with "Active Reconnaissance" activities like network scanning and cracking a WPA2-PSK WiFi password, then moves on to "Network and Web Exploitation" (including network-based attacks via Metasploit and common web app vulnerabilities), "Client-Side Exploitation" (such as browser-based attacks and malicious files), and concludes with an exploration of "Post Exploitation" activities such as privilege escalation. Students will use a variety of open source tools and scripts in a virtual machine environment to analyze provided files and conduct exploit demos.
objects.name: Penetration Testing Labs

objects.description: This micromodule contains two hands-on labs that address active reconnaissance in computer networks, including via WiFi. Different tools and procedures for vulnerability scanning and information gathering will be presented, such as simple scripting techniques, Nmap, NetCat, and OpenVAS. Students will learn how to apply these techniques to identify valuable characteristics of target networks for penetration testing purposes. Additionally, we will address potential recon opportunities in wireless security through exploitation of poor WiFi passwords in networks using WPA2-PSK security. Students will learn how to capture an access point handshake and crack the network password in a dictionary attack.
objects.name: Active Reconnaissance Labs

objects.description: Modern applications have grown increasingly complex, often operating over the Internet and crossing between networks (such as in cloud-assisted apps). Therefore, understanding the different vulnerabilities presented by networks and web-based applications is critical for both penetration testing and building safer system. This module contains two hands-on labs that will teach students the tools and techniques used to perform network-based and web-based exploitations during a pen test. Exercises will address using the Metasploit Framework, basic scanning with Python scripts, vulnerability scanning tools, and testing web exploits against the Damn Vulnerable Web Application (DVWA).
objects.name: Network & Web Exploitation Labs

objects.description: This micromodule contains one hands-on lab that walks students through a variety of client-side attacks that can be used during a penetration test. Client-side attacks target the end user devices rather than the web server or application. Students will walk through examples of performing website cloning, crafting malicious URLs for remote shell access, creating malicious PDF and EXE files, and be introduced to Powershell-based attacks.
objects.name: Client-Side Exploitation Lab

objects.description: This micromodule contains one hands-on lab that will explore different post-exploitation activities during a penetration test. Typically, the goal of post-exploitation activities involves accessing restricted information and/or gaining the privileges to have control over the system. These goals are based on the objective of the attack, such as stealing classified information, interfering with business processes, etc. In this lab, students will learn useful Meterpreter commands for information gathering and practice different ways to perform privilege escalation both with and without the Metasploit Framework.
objects.name: Post Exploitation Lab

objects.description:
This unit with 11 micromodules aims to explore an innovative security-integrated computer science education approach that can well address the following issues and help the nation intensively strengthen the cybersecurity education capacity:

  • Cybersecurity courses are not the core courses in the computer science curricula of the majority (if not all) of U.S. institutions.  This reality implies that cybersecurity has not been considered as an integral part of the computer science education in the first place. 
  • Many computer science courses do not include cybersecurity topics at all.  However, cybersecurity is closely related to almost all the other sub-areas of computer science.
  • Educators missed the golden chances of helping students understand the correlation and interplay between cybersecurity and other sub-areas of computer science.

All the micromodules are independent of each other.  Each of them includes the presentation slides and a survey.  Please read the overall instruction document ChuanYue_NSF_SFS_Overall_Instruction.pdf about how to use the 11 micromodules and then check the individual micromodules.
objects.name: Teaching Computer Science with Cybersecurity Education Built-in

objects.description:
A Presentation of the Research Paper “An Empirical Study of Cryptographic Misuse in Android Applications” (CCS 2013).  It is a very good topic to be integrated into non-security coursers such as Software Engineering, Software Testing, Mobile App Development, etc.

This micromodule is standalone and self-contained.   It includes the presentation slides and a survey.  Basically, an instructor or student with cybersecurity expertise can (1) discuss with the instructor of a non-security course to see if this micromodule could be relevant to the class and appropriate, (2) present the slides (with modifications if needed) in the non-security course, (3) discuss the topic with the students, and (4) use the survey (optional) to assess the teaching and learning effectiveness regarding the cybersecurity integration or injection activity.  It has four specific learning outcomes.
objects.name: Teaching Computer Science with Cybersecurity Education Built-in: Crypto API Misuse

objects.description:
A Presentation of Web Security and Privacy.  It is a very good topic to be integrated into non-security coursers such as Computer Networks, Web Development, etc.

This micromodule is standalone and self-contained.   It includes the presentation slides and a survey.  Basically, an instructor or student with cybersecurity expertise can (1) discuss with the instructor of a non-security course to see if this micromodule could be relevant to the class and appropriate, (2) present the slides (with modifications if needed) in the non-security course, (3) discuss the topic with the students, and (4) use the survey (optional) to assess the teaching and learning effectiveness regarding the cybersecurity integration or injection activity.  It has four specific learning outcomes.
objects.name: Teaching Computer Science with Cybersecurity Education Built-in: Web Security and Privacy

objects.description:
A Presentation of Malicious Code Injection - Its Attacks and Defenses.  It is a very good topic to be integrated into non-security coursers such as Operating Systems, Software Engineering, Software Testing, etc.

This micromodule is standalone and self-contained.   It includes the presentation slides and a survey.  Basically, an instructor or student with cybersecurity expertise can (1) discuss with the instructor of a non-security course to see if this micromodule could be relevant to the class and appropriate, (2) present the slides (with modifications if needed) in the non-security course, (3) discuss the topic with the students, and (4) use the survey (optional) to assess the teaching and learning effectiveness regarding the cybersecurity integration or injection activity.  It has five specific learning outcomes.
objects.name: Teaching Computer Science with Cybersecurity Education Built-in: Malicious Code Injection

objects.description: This course provides an introduction and overview of the changing nature of cybersecurity risk and how governments and companies are addressing this challenge with enterprise risk management and cybersecurity governance. The course explores the roles of Boards, Executive Committees, Chief Information Officers (CIOs), Chief Information Security Officers (CISOs) and General Counsels in cybersecurity; strategies and elements for developing a cybersecurity program; and governance, IT and cybersecurity risk frameworks.  The course also examines other issues related to cybersecurity risk including the cybersecurity legal and compliance environment; cybersecurity considerations for new technologies of mobile, IoT and cloud; fostering cybersecurity awareness; the role of key cybersecurity technologies; developing high performance cybersecurity teams; cybersecurity insurance; and the evolution of cybersecurity with orchestration and the potential and risk of AI.
objects.name: Enterprise Risk and Cybersecurity Governance

objects.description:
The course provides an overview of the industry and government paradigm shift with mobile and IoT and the resulting changing nature of cybersecurity risk and considerations for cybersecurity management and governance.

The course investigates the strategic, organizational, cybersecurity, privacy and compliance ramifications resulting from the rapid adoption of mobile and IOT and corresponding increase in the quantity and importance of data.   Topics include: the motivations for mobility strategy in the context of organizational strategy; the elements of mobile and IoT cybersecurity risk; considerations for developing a mobile cybersecurity strategy; mobile cybersecurity compliance and regulation;   mobile cybersecurity policies and approaches to enterprise mobility; application of the mobile device life cycle; evolution from mobile device to enterprise mobility to unified endpoint management; and the role of Boards, executive committees, general counsels, CIOs, CISOs and Chief Privacy Officers in mobile cybersecurity management.
objects.name: Mobile Cybersecurity Management (a)

objects.description: This module covers awareness of organizations, key standards, terms, and taxonomies related to publicly available secure coding guidelines
objects.name: Secure Coding Guidelines

objects.description: This nanomodule introduces students to the content and student learning outcomes associated with the course, "The Global Cyber Threat Environment."
objects.name: Introduction to the Global Cyber Threat Environment

objects.description: Module 2 relates the 1648 Treaty of Westphalia to the current state of cybersecurity and discusses the role of “soft power” in deterring cyber attacks. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Cyber Deterrence and the International System of Sovereignty

objects.description: Module 3 assesses the variety of cyber crimes and describes how terrorist organizations use technology to further their cause. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Cyber Terrorism and Cyber Crime

objects.description: Module 4 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on Russia’s cyber threat. This module discusses how Russia’s strategic cyber development has been affected by the country’s vast, open geographic characteristics as well as important historical differences between development of the West and of Russia. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Understanding the Russian Mindset

objects.description: Module 5 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on Russia’s cyber threat. This module discusses a range of cyber operations that Russia has executed against the United States as well as the historical nature of Russia’s interference in U.S. computer networks. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Russian Cyber Operations Background

objects.description: Module 6 will give an outline of the Russian agencies involved in conducting the country's cyber intelligence operations.
objects.name: Russian Cyber Intelligence

objects.description: Module 7 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on China’s cyber threat. This module discusses the historical development of China’s sense of cultural superiority and its concept of socialism. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Understanding the Chinese Mindset

objects.description: Module 8 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on China’s cyber threat. This module discusses the development and operations of China’s cyber enterprise. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Chinese Cyber Operations Background

objects.description: Module 9 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on China’s cyber threat. This module discusses the roles of Chinese intelligence agencies. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Chinese Cyber Intelligence

objects.description: Module 10 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on Iran’s cyber threat. This module discusses the development of the Shia sect of Islam and the role of the Shah in today’s Iran. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Understanding the Iranian Mindset

objects.description: Module 11 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on Iran’s cyber threat. This module highlights two main pillars of Iranian cyber strategy: ensuring regime survival through surveillance and information disruption, and creating a well-trained cyber workforce able to engage in both offensive and defensive cyber operations. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Iranian Cyber Operations Background

objects.description: Module 12 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on Iran’s cyber threat. This module focuses primarily on the cyber capabilities and organization of the Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps, or IRGC. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Iranian Cyber Intelligence

objects.description: Module 13 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on North Korea’s cyber threat. This module focuses on the history of North Korea’s “siege mentality.” The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: Understanding the North Korean Mindset

objects.description: Module 14 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on North Korea’s cyber threat. This module focuses on North Korea’s cyber strategy. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: North Korean Cyber Operations Background

objects.description: Module 15 is one of three modules in this lecture set that focuses on North Korea’s cyber threat. This module highlights a few of the North Korean intelligence organizations responsible for the country’s cyber operations. The module includes readings, a lecture video, a quiz, and an active learning activity.
objects.name: North Korean Cyber Intelligence

objects.description: Competency-based information template for Information Security Fundamentals
objects.name: Competency Based Education Project - Prince George's Community College

objects.description: This module utilizes the concept maps to provide a basic understanding of industrial control systems (ICS) including different components in ICS and how they work together. There are two common ICS types: Distributed Control System (DCS), and Supervisory Control and Data Acquisition (SCADA). This module also highlights their similarities and differences. Finally, it gives a conveyer belt example to help understand the working of a real-world ICS.
objects.name: Introduction to Industrial Control Systems

objects.description: This module is designed to provide basic Linux users with instruction in how to use multiple commands to accomplish a more complicated task than is done in a single command.
objects.name: Intro to Linux Commands for Security Students

objects.description: In memory-unsafe languages such as C and C++, the programmer has the ability to manipulate memory directly through dynamic allocation and commands that expose memory and data locations. Programmers thus have the responsibility to securely code such constructs when such languages are being used.  This module highlights the consequences and remedies of memory-based vulnerabilities, focusing on buffer-overflows as the preeminent example using the C language.
objects.name: Memory Based Vulnerabilities

objects.description: Advanced systems engineering concepts related to embedded Linux programming and Cybersecurity.  Students will gain experience with embedded Linux to include, initial setup of the operating system and support software, programming in assembly language, writing device drivers, adding functions to the Linux Kernel, creating a network stack to provide a presentation layer to an application program and creation of a sophisticated and complex application program written in C, in order to perform encryption and decryption on network traffic.
objects.name: Cybersecurity Systems Engineering

objects.description:
Blockchain is an emerging information technology dealing with current developments incloud computing, trust, and privacy. 

This field involves a fundamentally new approach to deal with databases, the need to develop new algorithms to secure transactions by proving trust among peers, storing information on decentralized computers, adopting rules of behavior known as byzantine fault tolerance, etc. 

This course adopts a multidisciplinary and interdisciplinary approach coming from computer engineering, behavior science, and cryptography domain. Starting from the first application in the financial sector (i.e. Bitcoin), Blockchain Technology is currently developing tools and platforms for a wide range of engineering management, social environment, and cyber security applications. 

This course is designed to prepare students for the federal job market in positions which require knowledge of applications of blockchain on cybersecurity.
objects.name: Blockchain and Cybersecurity

objects.description: This unit explains how blockchain works and presents insights from a cryptographic point of view. Blockchain fundamentally relies on public key cryptography. We will discuss how anonymity or pseudonymity, privacy, accountability and non-repudiation, and auditability are held through cryptographic tools such as hash chains, cryptographic signatures and encryption mechanisms. We will also present how Blockchain Technology was developed in time and became famous with Bitcoin.
objects.name: Fundamentals of Blockchain Technology

contributors.name: phillip nico
contributors.organization: california polytechnic state university-san luis obispo

objects.description: This is a diagnostic test for secure programming
objects.name: Secure Programming Concept Inventory

objects.description: This unit explains how a smart contract works. We will discuss how smart contracts can change the processes in different business applications. How to use Solidity coding language to make your own smart contract in Ethereum application. In addition, we will explore some useful implementations of blockchain in various sectors even in emerging areas such as Internet of Things and music industry.
objects.name: Blockchain Mechanisms for Architecting Business and Information Technology

objects.description: This unit explains what makes the blockchain mechanism more secure and how it can be used to improve cybersecurity of different kind of businesses and government processes. This unit provides insights on cybersecurity challenges and the aspects of blockchain that can help to overcome the challenges.
objects.name: Application of Blockchain to Boost Cybersecurity

objects.description: Bitcoin is the application of blockchain technology that made it famous. This micromodule provides the fundamentals of blockchain technology. The topics in this micromodule include basics about blockchain, blockchain technology advent & bitcoin, cryptocurrencies, and blockchain technology evolution.
objects.name: Basics of Blockchain and Cryptocurrencies

objects.description: This micromodule includes the following topics: blockchain technology mechanism, types of blockchains, advantages and challenges of blockchain adoption, and the future of the blockchain technology.
objects.name: Blockchain Technology Mechanism

objects.description:
In this micromodule, students will learn about the topics below:

The main concepts of Blockchain are described with the algorithms that can be used to implement the Blockchain. 

The main concepts are distributed systems, fault tolerance, consensus, Byzantine agreement, authenticated agreement, quorum systems, eventual consistency, and consistent hashing.
objects.name: Science of Blockchain

objects.description: In this micromodule, students will learn about cryptography and its applicability in the Blockchain context. Then, students will gain familiarity with the main application of Blockchain beyond just financial transactions. Finally, the students will learn about distributed computing with its main advantages and challenges and how distributed computing will affect changes in the future.
objects.name: Blockchain and Cryptography

objects.description: Smart contract is one of the most popular application of blockchain technology. This micromodule provides the fundamentals of a smart contract and its application in businesses. The topics in this micromodule includes basic concepts, smart contract mechanism, advantages and disadvantages of smart contracts, and regulatory aspects of smart contracts.
objects.name: Smart Contracts

objects.description: This micromodule provides insights about how applications of smart contract are implemented using Ethereum smart contract mechanism and Solidity coding language. This micromodule has examples on Ethereum applications. With the lab related to this topic, students will have hands-on experience on Solidity and Ethereum.
objects.name: Ethereum and Solidity

objects.description: In this micromodule, students will learn about topics such as blockchain as a service, Ricardian contract, different kinds of applications by sectors, such as finance, supply chain, and public service.
objects.name: Blockchain Applications for Business

objects.description: In this micromodule, the student will learn about topics such as applications for Internet of Things, utilities, music, art, and healthcare sector.
objects.name: Blockchain Applications for Emerging Sectors

objects.description: In this micromodule, we will explore how secure the blockchain and smart contracts are. We will have more depth into the criminal activities where Bitcoin is used. Finally, we will give insights about possible attacks to the blockchain technology.
objects.name: Security of Blockchain Technology

objects.description: In this micromodule, we will explore what makes the transaction and verification processes of blockchain secure, what scalability measures are, how the security of blockchain can be enhanced, and how blockchain supports privacy of its users.
objects.name: Security Features and Privacy of Blockchain Technology

objects.description: In this micromodule, students will review the topics including the advantages and challenges of blockchain, learn the principles of cybersecurity and how blockchain can be used to enhance cybersecurity from the perspective of Confidentiality, Integrity, and Availability.
objects.name: Blockchain Technology for Cybersecurity

objects.description: In this micromodule, students will learn about the traditional, blockchain specific, and open challenges of using blockchain technology for cybersecurity, and the possible solutions for using blockchain technology for cybersecurity.
objects.name: Challenges and Recommendations for using Blockchain Technology for Cybersecurity

objects.description:
This course will familiarize students with the technical aspects of Windows host forensics. Students will learn how to use open source tools to make images; capture volatile data; perform file system, network traffic, memory, and disk image analysis; defeat simple anti-forensics techniques, use open source information to aid their investigations, and write professional reports on their findings.

Upon completion of this module, students will be able to: 

  • Create forensically sound disk images and memory captures
  • Assess common Windows and NTFS artifacts
  • Collect recovered data through file carving and data recovery techniques
  • Create and extract information from memory captures and hibernation files
  • Create professional reports on the results of their analysis
  • Manage e-mail databases through recovery and analysis
  • Discuss basic anti-forensics techniques
  • Assess functionality of malware to the extent possible without reverse engineering
  • Evaluate network traffic
  • Construct a professional forensics workstation using open source forensics tools 
  • Create a complete forensics examination
objects.name: Applied Cyber Forensics

objects.description: This module utilizes the concept maps to provide the basic concepts of computer security, common tools and their usage, information of cyber security attacks and countermeasures, security requirements and strategies, and terminology. Later modules will detail the topics presented in this module.
objects.name: Introduction to Computer Security

objects.description: This module utilizes the concept maps to provide a basic understanding of user authentication including different means of authentication with symmetric and asymmetric encryption algorithms, and password authentication processes of selection, checking, and cracking. Also, the material will elaborate upon and authentication with tokens and biometrics. Later modules consist of more specific aspects of computer security and will be expanded upon in more detail.
objects.name: User authentication

objects.description: This module gives a brief understanding of the basic concepts and usage of cryptographic tools.
objects.name: Cryptographic Tools

objects.description: This module utilizes the concept maps to provide a basic understanding of malicious software including malware terminology, classifications of malware attacks, mechanisms of propagation, and defense strategies. This module also presents countermeasures to virus and worm attacks. Lastly, it gives descriptions and examples of malicious software payloads.
objects.name: Malware

objects.description: This module gives a brief understanding of the basic concepts of denial-of-service attacks, classifications of attacks, and countermeasures.
objects.name: Denial-of-Service Attacks

objects.description: This module gives a brief understanding of the basic concepts of buffer overflow, classifications of the different types, and common defenses and countermeasures
objects.name: Buffer Overflow

objects.description: This module gives a brief understanding of the basic concepts of intrusion detection, classifications of intrusions and scenario examples, and various mechanisms of intrusion detection
objects.name: Intrusion Detection

objects.description: This module gives a brief understanding of the basic concepts of access control. The lessons will further explain discretionary and role-based access control
objects.name: Access Control

objects.description:
The objective of this course is to utilize concept maps to cover the following eight modules.

  1. Intro to Computer Security
  2. User Authentication
  3. Cryptographic Tools
  4. Malware
  5. DOS Attacks
  6. Buffer Overflow
  7. Intrusion Detection
  8. Access Controls
objects.name: Computer Security

objects.description: This module provides a brief overview of digital evidence including the location and types of evidence, creating a documentation for an evidence, and legal aspects pertaining to evidence.
objects.name: Introduction to Digital Forensics

objects.description: This module focuses on how a digital forensics investigator should respond to a case before starting the investigation, what are the necessary steps and procedures which should be taken care of and how the evidence should be handled.
objects.name: First Response and Investigation

objects.description: This module focuses on the steps/tasks that should be performed during a forensic investigation including the acquisition and analysis of the evidence, and the reporting that describes the entire investigation procedure and give a conclusion on a case.
objects.name: Digital Forensics Investigation Steps

objects.description: This module focuses on file system investigation. It provides an overview of different file system, file allocation table, new technology file system, and investigating tips and techniques on file system.
objects.name: Introduction To File System

objects.description: This module focuses on memory analysis and live forensics. It explains volatility data and how important the data is for investigation. This module also discusses volatility framework, which is a popular for investigating volatile data. It explains the volatility plugins.
objects.name: Memory/Live Forensics

objects.description: This module focuses on the usage of different tools and techniques for filesystem investigation including sleuth kit.
objects.name: Tools For Filesystem Investigation

objects.description:
The objective of this course is to utilize concept maps to cover the following six modules on digital forensics.

  1. Intro to Digital Forensics
  2. First Response Investigator
  3. Investigation Steps
  4. File systems
  5. Memory Forensics
  6. Filesystem Analysis Tools
objects.name: Digital Forensics

objects.description: This module provides a brief understanding of how penetration tests can be performed. A range of methods of reconnaissance and exploitation are described including information gathering, finding vulnerabilities, capturing traffic, password attack, wireless attack, and web application testing.
objects.name: Introduction To  Penetration Testing

objects.description: Reconnaissance is the first step in performing penetration testing. It includes information gathering from open source intelligence, port scanning, vulnerability discovery, and network traffic capturing. In this module, various methods of reconnaissance and commonly used tools are discussed
objects.name: Reconnaissance

objects.description: This module gives an understanding of how the scanning process can be performed to search for vulnerabilities. It discusses various methods of port scanning using the Nmap tool. The Dig tool for querying domain name system (DNS) servers is also described in this module.
objects.name: Scanning

objects.description: This module gives sufficient understanding of exploitation methods using the popular penetration testing software, Metasploit. Various commands and options of Metasploit are covered in this module
objects.name: Exploitation

objects.description: This module describes how passwords stored in systems and discusses various password attack methods including brute force attack, dictionary attack, and rainbow table attack. Several password cracking tools are also introduced in this material
objects.name: Password Attacks

objects.description: This Module gives deep understanding of wireless (IEEE 802.11) security. Wireless security algorithms and protocols such as Wired equivalent privacy (WEP), Wi-Fi protected access (WPA), and WPA2 are discussed here. Various attack methods for each of them will also be introduced in this module.
objects.name: Wireless Security

objects.description:
The objective of this course is to utilize concept maps to cover the following six modules on Network Penetration Testing.

  1. Introduction to Penetration Testing
  2. Reconnaissance
  3. Scanning
  4. Exploitation
  5. Password Attacks
  6. Wireless Security
objects.name: Network Penetration Testing

objects.description:
The goal of this learning object is to  provide both depth and breadth of understanding of cybersecurity issues in embedded hardware and software systems.

The lab exercises contained in this object can be used as part of a course on Secure Embedded Systems at the graduate or undergraduate level.

These objectives and outcomes of the lab exercises are described in detail.
objects.name: Secure Embedded Systems

objects.description: Data Science is a critical skill for CyberSecurity professionals to analyze, detect, and counter threats. This proposed course on advanced data science will be designed to enable cybersecurity professionals across a range of work roles to master fundamental skills of advanced data science, including statistical analysis, regression, machine learning, and big data analysis tools and techniques. Course modules will be able to stand alone, allowing students – including those not focused on cybersecurity -  to master on specific data science skills. All modules will include extensive exercises with real world data, often from cybersecurity contexts, to illustrate the use of tools and applications of techniques taught.
objects.name: Advanced Data Science

objects.description:
This module will follow on from the regression analysis covered in the previous module. Students will learn about the relationship between regression and classification and how classification works at a high level. We will also revisit regression to see how it is used as a machine learning technique. Students will learn how to format data for use in machine learning tools, both within R / SPSS and in the open-source machine learning tool Weka. We will study the major types of machine learning algorithms: Bayesian models, trees, rule-based systems, neural networks.

Then we will see how to build these models and how to statistically interpret the results. By the end of this module, students will be able to take datasets and build machine learning models to classify or predict values with commonly used tools.
objects.name: Predictive Analytics: Machine Learning

objects.description:
This module will focus on identifying and understanding the major types of data problems and techniques for cleaning them. Hands on exercises will use R or SPSS as well as the excellent open-source data cleaning tool OpenRefine. 

We will address the following data issues:

  • Duplicate and redundant records
  • Missing data fields
  • Date validation
  • Use of multiple numeric scales and ranges
  • Multiple representations of the same data (e.g. "VP" and "Vice President")
  • Summation data
  • Spelling errors

Exercises will use real datasets and students will apply a variety of techniques and heuristics to produce cleaned data.
objects.name: Data Cleaning

objects.description:
This module will introduce simple and multiple linear regression and logistic regression models to students. This module will begin by refreshing students on variables and correlation, as relatively strong correlations are necessary before undertaking regression modeling. Students will learn to calculate statistics by hand (e.g. sum of residuals) and using tools like R or SPSS.

Topics covered will include:

  • Simple and Multiple Linear Regression
  • Logistic Regression
  • Estimation of Coefficients
  • Indicator, Dummy, Derived & Interaction Variables
  • Collinearity 

Students will also look at the effect size and overall significance for the models so that they may properly interpret the results. Exercises will include simple examples to test each element as it is covered plus larger exercises to illustrate the complexity and depth of results that regression analysis can achieve.
objects.name: Predictive Analytics: Linear and Logistic Regression

objects.description: This module will introduce the core statistical concepts of network analysis as a data science technique. We will begin by reviewing the basic concepts of network structure – nodes, edges, and paths. Then, we will cover the core statistics for understanding the importance of entities in networks, including centrality measures (closeness, degree, betweenness, eigenvector), connected components, and community detection. Students will learn how to calculate these values by hand and using existing tools in R/SPSS and in the open source network analysis tool Gephi. Exercises will use real world data from cybersecurity attacks to illustrate the techniques and their application to cybersecurity issues.
objects.name: Network Analysis

objects.description:
This module will introduce cluster processing, the Map Reduce structure with a specific focus on the Hadoop system as provided through AWS Amazon EMR, and the map and reduce processes.

We will begin with the basics of parallel, distributed computing with examples of how problems can be broken up, distributed, and then have the results re-assembled. We will explore how parallelization is handled in Map Reduce with a specific focus on Hadoop MapReduce. This will integrate with the architecture we learned first, giving students knowledge of the mapping and reducing steps along with the roles of Master and Worker processes. Students will complete exercises to implement basic MapReduce programs.

Next, we will look at common data analysis algorithms that use MapReduce. These include matrix algebra operations and relational algebra (including selections, projections, and aggregation). We will integrate material on determining the complexity and costs of computations using Map Reduce and how to work with Workflows. The module will conclude with a larger, real-world Map Reduce computation exercise to give students realistic experience with the tools and techniques.
objects.name: Map Reduce and Hadoop

objects.description:
This module will leverage the AWS Kinesis streaming data service which supports data analysis over streams. 

The content of this module will focus on the major challenges streaming data presents and how to effectively use it with techniques students already know. We will address the following major challenges:

  • How to sample, filter, and count elements in a data stream
  • How to estimate moments 
  • How to query over sliding time windows

Students will learn a variety of sampling algorithms and methods, how to estimate error in queries or statistics calculated on a sampled stream, and algorithms for data filtering. 

Exercises will focus on cybersecurity-related examples. We plan to specifically address the detection of attacks (e.g. DDoS attacks) in real time by analyzing IP data streams.
objects.name: Mining Data Streams

objects.description:
This will be an exceptionally hands-on model, introducing students to the Data Analytics tools offered through Amazon Web Services (AWS) and how to use them, specifically in the context of analytics for cybersecurity. Students will have already seen the Hadoop and Kinesis products. This module will introduce additional tools and their use through the command line interface, web interfaces, and in code.

This module will introduce the following additional tools and material:

  • S3 (Simple Storage Solution)
  • Glue
  • DataPipeline
  • Athena
  • Elasticsearch
  • QuickSight
  • Redshift

We will provide students with several large datasets to work with. For each tool above, we will have hands on exercises using those datasets so students get a full range of experience with each.
objects.name: Data Analytics with AWS

objects.description:
This course covers fundamental problems, principles, and practical problem solving techniques in cryptography, web, binary reversing, binary exploitation, forensics, and firmware analysis; many of the techniques will be demonstrated and practiced using commonly used and customized tools using Python. 

Learning objectives:

  • Evaluate common weaknesses in implementations of cryptographic algorithms
  • Implement cryptanalysis of substitution and commonly used ciphers
  • Assess common web application vulnerabilities 
  • Formulate SQL injections to exploit vulnerable web applications 
  • Assess binary programs in x86
  • Determine how to exploit buffer overflow and string format vulnerabilities 
  • Develop and use shell code 
  • Code python scripts to solve various cyber security problems 
  • Assess common file formats (ELF, PE, PDF, etc.)
objects.name: Practical Cyber Operations Fundamentals & Offensive Computer Security

objects.description: This course provides an introductory but comprehensive coverage of fundamental problems, principles, and techniques in software reverse engineering of binaries including static analysis techniques, disassembly algorithms, dynamic analysis techniques, automated static and dynamic analysis techniques, malware analysis techniques, anti-analysis techniques, and malware obfuscation and packing techniques; many of the techniques will be demonstrated and practiced using IDA. It also involves research opportunities to analyze new malware samples.
objects.name: Reverse Engineering & Malware Analysis

objects.description: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background on data preprocessing and feature extraction. The module is divided into two lessons, where the first one gives students a general background on text mining and crawling the web, and the second one teaches students how to preprocess textual data and extract important features from text.
objects.name: Background For Data Preprocessing, Feature Extraction

objects.description: This module aims to give students a comprehensive background in text classification. The module is divided into two lessons, that introduces efficient classification techniques to be used to classify the feature formerly mentioned and classifiers performance evaluation.
objects.name: Predictive Analytics

objects.description: This module aims to give students a comprehensive background on Spark Streaming and Event Data analysis. The module is divided into two sub-modules. First sub-module introduces Big Data, Spark and its different components, Spark Streaming, Kafka, and text classification using Spark. Second sub-module introduces event data access, analysis, and prediction.
objects.name: Window-based Stream Data Analytics with SPARK and Kafka

objects.description: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background on stream data processing and novel class detection. The module is divided into three lessons. The 1st lesson teaches students the fundamentals of stream mining and anomaly detection. The 2nd lesson gives a comprehensive background on novel class detection in data streams. Finally, the 3rd lesson teaches students robust novel class detection technique in high dimensional data stream.
objects.name: On-line Stream Analytics

objects.description: This unit will examine software testing approaches, coverage criteria and tools for detecting potential software faults and security weaknesses that could lead to exploitable vulnerabilities in software applications as well as examining and applying testing approaches targeting security requirements.
objects.name: Software Testing Techniques and Tools

objects.description:
This course will cover the fundamental concepts related to machine learning for cyber security. Topics include:

  • Deep Learning and Tensorflow
  • Features and Feature extraction
  • KNN, Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, Neural Nets, and Deep Neural Nets
  • Performance Metrics
  • ML applications: Malware, IOT detection, intrusion detection, Phishing, etc.
  • Unsupervised Machine Learning

Prerequisites: Programming skills up to data structures and knowledge of statistics will be useful. No prior experience with machine learning is required.
objects.name: Machine Learning for Cybersecurity

objects.description: This is a learning OBject
objects.name: Module

objects.description:
Overview

To get you a grasp of how PKI works, this lab simulates the issuance, revocation, and installation process of digital certificates. Specifically, you will do all your experiments in the GENI environment, and go through those processes with the help of OpenSSL, a widely used cryptographic toolkit. The tasks are divided into three lab modules. The first module focuses on certificate issuance and revocation; the second module focuses on the chain of trust; and the third module simulates a scenario of man-in-the-middle attack against this infrastructure. Since there are quite a few overlaps between these modules, follow the order would help you go through them.

Environment

GENI is a cloud-based networking experimentation testbed. For each lab module, you have to create a separate slice in GENI, and reserve resources as described in lab manuals. After the resources are available, connect to those VMs through ssh and do the correspondent tasks. If you have difficulty setting up the environment, please refer to the beginner's guide for how to use GENI.
objects.name: Digital Certificate Introduction Labs

objects.description:
Introduction

Since the advent of Bitcoin, there have been lots of blockchain frameworks and implementations invented. Generally, they fall into two categories, one is the permission ( private ) blockchain, and the other is the public blockchains. The permission blockchains only allow authorized people to join, while public blockchains allow anyone to be its member. This is the most prevailing way that people classify blockchains.

However, some people are not satisfied with this categorization. They argued about the legitimacy of blockchain being permissioned. In a private blockchain, the trust is no more decentralized and transparent, and it is hard to find any difference between permission blockchains and decentralized database. As a result, they don't even view private blockchains as real blockchains.

In this lab, you will try to build a certificate management application using smart contract in Hyperledger Fabric in a private blockchain. You will first build the environment, run their sample code, Fabcar, then finally rewrite/replace some of the code in it.
objects.name: Blockchain for Digital Certificate Management Lab

objects.description:
The Andor Assembly Language Programming Contest is a pre-built VM and problem set(s) for conducting a CTF-like contest using several architectures. 

A unique aspect of this contest is that the assembly language portions will be for several CPU instruction set architectures. Many participating teams would likely be familiar with x86-32 or x86-64, and one set of problems is devoted to x86-64. The second problem set will require the students to program in ARM using an ARM 7 simulator.  The third set is unique in that the students will be given the documentation for a (fictitious) CPU including details on the layout of the instructions and their exact operation.
objects.name: Assembly Language Programming Contest - Main Contest, documentation, solutions

objects.description: These are problems in assembly language for the Andor programming contest. This is the ARM 7 content.
objects.name: ARM 7 Problems - Assembly Language Programming Contest

objects.description: Problems for the assembly language programming contest that use the "Really Reduced Instruction Set Computer".
objects.name: RRISC Problems - Assembly Language Programming Contest

objects.description: For the assembly language programming contest, these are x86-64 problems to be completed on a Linux platform.
objects.name: x86-64 Problems - Assembly Language Programming Contest

Labs 1 through 9 must use an AWS virtual machine instantiated from a custom Amazon Machine Image created specifically for these lab assignments. The AMI may be located by its ID: ami-049c5743a562ad3ef. It is recommended to apply for AWS Educate program, which provides with free AWS credit. This credit may be used for completing the lab assignments. By default, AWS allocates $50 credit per student. This amount may be increased by the applicant.
