objects.description:
This micromodule gives a review of the fundamentals of digital systems and the design of combinational digital logic circuits. Although it is a review, students with no or little background on digital design can learn, from this micromodule, the concepts and skills that are needed for the rest of the course on hardware security and reverse engineering.

After a brief description of digital systems, we focus on the specification and implmentation of digital systems. We discuss the need of simplification (i.e. design optimization). The don't care conditions are an advanced topic which might be suitable for seniors or graduate students. We conclude with an example of technology mapping, which is an important concept in real life circuit implementation.

Six detailed examples:
1. system specification on a design that tells whether a given month has 31 days
2. prove that a given gate (or a set of gates) is universal
3. concept of satisfiability don't care (SDC) 
4. concept of observability don't care (ODC)
5. design optimization with SDC
6. design optimization with ODC

materials:
26 slides
14 quiz questions and 11 exam problems
objects.name: Introduction to combinational digital logic design

objects.description:
This micromodule gives a brief review of the fundamentals of memory units (latch and flip-flop) and the design of sequential digital logic circuits. We also cover several key concepts that are needed for the rest of the course on hardware security and trust.

We first introduce the basic sequential system design concepts: latch, flip-flop, design with flop flops, state representation of sequential system. We focus on two concepts that normal introduction digital logic design course does not cover: self-correcting design and finite state machine equivalence  check. These two concepts are directly related to the security and trust of sequentical systems.

Six detailed examples:
1. how the NOR gate latch stores one bit of information.
2. how the clocked SR flip-flop stores one bit of information.
3. sequential system specification of a pattern generator
4. sequential system design of a simple state machine
5. self-correcting design
6. FSM equivalence check

materials:
20 slides
10 quiz questions and 4 exam problems
objects.name: Introduction to sequential digital logic design

objects.description:
In this micromodule, we study various ways of physical attacks to hardware and chips. Through such study, we will see the threats from hardware and how to break security from hardware. We will also learn some of the countermeasures to these attacks. We will also learn how industry and government define and evaluate the security levels of a product. More specifically, this micromodule covers the following topics:

1. basic concepts (requirements and procedure) of physical attacks.
2. Classification of physical attackers and physical attacks.
3. Characteristics, examples, tools and skills, countermeasures for each type of physical attacks.
4. government and industry standards on tamper protection level and security levels.
5. recommended procedure to secure a system.

materials:
29 slides
8 quiz questions and 8 exam problems
objects.name: Physical attacks to hardware and countermeasures

objects.description:
This nanomodule describes the roles of computer hardware in security and trust. The key message we want to deliver is that the computing and communication devices are not secure and they cannot be trusted for granted.

We will focus on the security vulnerabilities introduced by hardware. Threats from side channel attacks, hardware Trojan, and untrusted microchip supply chain will be discussed with illustrative examples. The module concludes with a high level overview of the key problems/challenges in hardware security, namely securing the design and design intellectual properties; securing the computation and data; and providing hardware security primitives.

Two detailed examples:
1. modular exponentiation and power analysis attack
2. trust in digital logic designs (both combinational and sequential circuits)?

materials:
20 slides
7 quiz questions and 7 exam problems
objects.name: Hardware security and trust

objects.description:
This micromodule covers the basics of CMOS chip fabrication, packaging, and testing. It is important to understand this process so we can investigate how reverse engineering will be performed. 

materials:
31 slides
objects.name: Introduction to Chip fabrication, testing, and packaging

objects.description:
This module covers the reverse engineering of CMOS chips. It contains the following topics:
1. Design of basic CMOS gates (Inverter, NAND, NOR)
2. Layout of sample CMOS gates (Inverter, NAND)
3. Chip fabrication process with inverter as an example
4. Chip test and packaging
5. Basic concepts of reverse engineering (definitions, legal code, , motivation)
6. Chip destructive setup
7. Physical and functional analysis


materials:
70 slides
objects.name: Hardware Reverse Engineering

objects.description:
This module covers the following detective countermeasures for reverse engineering: digital watermark, digital fingerprint, and hardware metering. We first discuss design intellectual property (IP), which is widely used in modern chip design, and the motivation of IP protection where reverse engineering is one of the main threats. Then we elaborate digital watermark, fingerprint, and hardware metering methods with focus on watermarking and fingerprinting.  

materials:
62 slides
objects.name: Detective Countermeasures to Reverse Engineering

objects.description:
This module provides a comprehensive coverage of side channel attacks (SCA) and their countermeasures. We start with the definition of SCA and its key features, as well as the major sources of side channel for modern systems. We then elaborate the vulnerabilities in memory side channel and several well-known cache attacks. Next, we consider modular exponentiation, the most fundamental mathematical operation in modern cryptography, and explain how cryptographical keys could leak because of in-secure implementation of modular exponentiation. More specifically, we elaborate the power analysis attacks. Finally, we review the currently available countermeasures to side channel attacks at the levels of hardware, software, and algorithm.

materials:
70 slides
objects.name: Side Channel Attacks and Countermeasures

objects.description: This software provides a team competition that may be run on a variety of closed network environments from a collection of laptops to a cyber range.  Teams attempt to accumulate wealth by legitimate means as well as by theft.  Wealth is managed with respect to an 'economy', consisting of a set of 10 resources, which is controlled by a single running monitor program.  Teams build client software that communicates with the Monitor and with other clients via the Monitor.  Communication may include requests for trades of resources, requests to build weapons from the resources, and requests to wage wars with other clients.  A ready-made client, with GUI, is provided for the middle and high school populations where expertise in coding is not expected.  Any kind of nefarious activity, such as ARP poisoning, is allowed in the competition.  The Monitor is written in C.  More advanced versions of the competition will have the Monitor binary distributed to all teams for forensic analysis - vulnerabilities will be intentionally added.  The competition is intended to contribute to the quality and quantity of the Cyber Operations community by reducing time to appenticeships.
objects.name: Cyber Operations Competition

objects.description: This module presents race conditions. It begins by covering the interaction of concurrent processes accessing shared variables. It then demonstrates the security problems that can arise, and how to prevent them. Both time-of-check to time-of-use (TOCTTOU) race conditions, in the guise of accessing files, and race conditions arising from asynchronous interrupts, are presented.
objects.name: A Primer on Race Conditions and Computer Security

objects.description:
Module Description: Security requirement analysis is a critical process in software development to better understand threats and risks for mission critical requirements. This module focuses on how to identify a software application’s goal and context at the software requirements phase so that threat and risk analysis can be performed.

Prerequisite Knowledge: Students are expected to have the basic knowledge of software development.

Length of Completion: Micro-Module – About 4 hours

Level of Instruction: This module is intended for undergraduate/graduate. This module is intended for CS and related majors.

Learning Setting: Is this intended for online/in-class/hybrid.

Lab Environment: Students can carry out assignments using common document creating tools such as Microsoft Office.

Activity/Lab Tasks: Students will learn how to create logical and physical views of a software based on high-level requirements. The logical view will include the context diagram as well as level-1 data flow diagram.

Lab Files that are Needed:  High level requirements of three software applications will be provided.
objects.name: Software Security Goals and Context

objects.description: Programming rarely requires writing all code from scratch; rather, programmers should use suitable libraries and frameworks (“packages”), when possible. However, not all application programming interfaces (APIs) provided by such packages have the same level of security: Some can be used in a way that will introduce vulnerabilities. This module covers the importance of using security-aware packages, and using those packages’ APIs in a secure manner. Examples of improper and proper use will be given.
objects.name: Using secure APIs, Securely

objects.description: Programming mistakes that are the source of vulnerabilities are inevitable. Fortunately, certain operating system and compiler-based defenses can make it more difficult to exploit these vulnerabilities in a deployed system. Adversary access to executable code is also a problem if the code has confidentiality or integrity requirements. This module presents several defenses that can help, shows how to use them, explains how they work, and assesses their strengths and limitations.
objects.name: Deployment-time Defenses

objects.description: No software system will ever be completely perfect. Over time, missed vulnerabilities will be discovered, and features will be added which introduce new vulnerabilities. As such, securing software requires putting in place a process to patch that software, post-deployment. It also requires a mechanism for considering, assessing, and addressing discovered vulnerabilities. This module covers the principles and practices of securing software as it evolves. It also explores an empirical study of post-deployment evolution.
objects.name: Post-deployment Evolution and Patching

author.name: laurie williams
author.organization: north carolina state university at raleigh

objects.description: Security requirement analysis is a critical process in software development to better understand threats and risks for mission critical requirements. This module focuses on how to identify and analyze threats, risks, and security requirements, covering topics such as abuse cases, threat modeling, and attack/defense trees.
objects.name: Threat and Risk Analysis

author.name: laurie williams
author.organization: north carolina state university at raleigh

objects.description: Secure coding begins with the design of a secure program or system.  At the foundation of secure design are software security principles.  This module provides background on 21 important principles of secure software design and their role to address important implementation- and design-level security vulnerabilities.
objects.name: Software Security Principles

objects.description: The goal of this module is to identify how different numerical data types can be misinterpreted in a function or method. The focus of this module are Integral data types such as characters, short integers, integers, long integers of both signed and unsigned data. The module will describe and demonstrate vulnerabilities such as Integer Overflow and Underflow and their potential implications.
objects.name: Numerical Data Handling-Overflow and Underflow

objects.description: Session-based vulnerabilities occur when attackers can maliciously use a user’s session to gain access to a system without having to authenticate. This module will cover session hijacking, and should be paired with the existing module on Cross Site Request Forgery (CSRF) in order to cover two common session-based vulnerabilities.
objects.name: Session-based vulnerabilities

contributors.name: laurie williams
contributors.organization: north carolina state university at raleigh

objects.description: A major step in the security life cycle is design, and the design of a system needs to enforce security requirements. This module focuses on the process and activities of software design for implementing secure software as well as common software security design flaws. The module includes two lessons, two reading assignments on security architecture and security design analysis, followed by a homework assignment.
objects.name: Software Design for Security

objects.description: This module aims to give the students a comprehensive background on Probabilistic modeling and Deep Neural Networks. The module is divided into two lessons. The 1st lesson teaches students the fundamentals of Bayesian network models, Maximum likelihood estimation, and MAP estimation. The 2nd lesson teaches students topic modeling, Generative and Discriminative models, and Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA).
objects.name: Probabilistic Models and Deep Neural Networks

objects.description:
Credit card sized and inexpensive Pyboards allow running scripts using MicroPython to develop microcontroller based system design. In this micromodule, three laboratory exercises involving 7-segment displays, LED-based traffic light controller and real-time temperature data acquisition and encryption are included. We emphasize data security for transmission and/or storage in the real-time temperature data acquisition and encryption lab exercise.

These labs allow students to quickly experiment with interfacing various sensors and transducers using a scripting language. Yet the microcontroller at the heart of the Pyboard is powerful enough and the Pyboard supports most of the conventional interfaces, e.g., ADC, DAC, PWM, Servo control, UART, I2C, SPI, CAN, etc. for developing a plethora of embedded applications. Newer versions of Pyboard also support Wi-fi and Bluetooth communication interfaces.
objects.name: Microcontroller Based System Design Using MicroPython on Pyboard
